Description: NATURE NEXUS INSTITUTE (NNI) WILL CONTINUE TO EXPAND ITS COMMUNITY NATURE CONNECTIONS AIMED AT PROVIDING EQUITABLE ACCESS TO NATURE-BASED ACTIVITIES THAT DEEPEN PARTICIPANTS  SENSE OF BELONGING IN THE GREAT OUTDOORS.

BAND RETURNS ARE THE PRIMARY SOURCE OF DATA USED IN WOOD DUCK HARVEST MANAGEMENT IN NORTH AMERICA. WITHOUT ADEQUATE BANDING, WOOD DUCK HUNTING SEASONS COULD FAIL TO BE OPENED OR THE PUPATION COULD BE AT RISK OF OVERHARVEST. THE SOUTHEAST REGIONS WATERFOWL MONITORING PLAN ALLOCATED SPECIFIC WOOD DUCK BANDING GOALS FOR EACH STATE, INCLUDING ARKANSAS, WHICH SHOULD BE MET ANNUALLY USING A COOPERATIVE BANDING PROGRAM. THE US. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HAS STAFFING SHORTFALLS THAT REQUIRE ASSISTANCE FROM PARTNER COLLABORATIONS TO HELP MEET BANDING GOALS. OBJECTIVE(S): 1) CAPTURE AND BAND WOOD DUCKS AND OTHER MIGRATORY WATERFOWL DURING JUNE  SEPTEMBER 2023 TO SUPPORT WOOD DUCK BANDING OBJECTIVES FOR THE CENTRAL ARKANSAS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX AND DEMONSTRATE ACTIVE WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING ON REFUGES.2) CAPTURE, BAND, AND AUXILIARY MARK (AS NEEDED AND REQUESTED) MIGRATORY WATERFOWL DURING WINTER 2023 2024 TOSUPPORT RESEARCH AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES IN THE CENTRAL ARKANSAS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX.3) ASSIST STAFF WITHIN THE CENTRAL ARKANSAS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR) COMPLEX IN WATERFOWL MANAGEMENT AND MONITORING ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING TRAP SITE PREPARATION, WETLAND INFRASTRUCTURE MAINTENANCE, AND OTHER DUTIES ASDIRECTED.METHODS WE WILL CAPTURE AND LEG-BAND WOOD DUCKS DURING THE PRESEASON PERIOD (JULY 1  30 SEPTEMBER) AND OTHER MIGRATORY WATERFOWL DURING THE WITHIN (1 NOVEMBER  31 JANUARY) OR 1 FEBRUARY  31 MARCH) POST-SEASON PERIOD IN COORDINATION WITH STAFF FROM CENTRAL ARKANSAS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR) COMPLEX. OUR GOAL WILL BE TO CAPTURE AND LEG-BAND A MINIMUM OF 500 WOOD DUCKS ON EACH OF HOLLA BEND (N   200), CACHE RIVER (N   200), AND BALD KNOB NWR (N   100). WE WILL USE SWIM IN, ROCKET NET, AND DROP GATE (IF AVAILABLE) TRAPS BAITED WITH WHEAT (SUPPLIED BY  THE USFWS) OR ANOTHER ATTRACTANT. UNIVERSITY STAFF WILL ERECT AND MONITOR 2-3 TRAP SITES PER REFUGE DURING THE  PRESEASON PERIOD AND MAY ASSIST WITH CAPTURE DURING WITHIN-SEASON OR POST-SEASON CAPTURE EFFORTS AT THE REQUEST OF THE SERVICE AS NEEDED. BANDING WILL BE COMPLETED UNDER ALL NECESSARY STATE AND FEDERAL PERMITS.  ALL BANDING WILL BE DONE COLLABORATIVELY BY SERVICE STAFF AND UNIVERSITY STAFF. PROJECT PERSONNEL UNIVERSITY STAFF (DR. DOUGLAS OSBORNE) WILL HIRE AND SUPERVISE UNIVERSITY STAFF USING SKILLS AND JOB DUTIES HEREIN TO SELECT APPROPRIATE PERSONNEL. SERVICE STAFF (DR. CHRIS SWANSON, DR. HEATH HAGY, RICHARD CROSSETT, PAUL PROVENCE, AND OTHERS) HAVE  10 YEARS OF WATERFOWL TRAPPING AND MANAGEMENT EXPERIENCE EACH AND WILL HELP DESIGN  THE PROJECT, SELECT TRAPPING SITES, TRAIN UNIVERSITY PERSONNEL, AND ASSIST WITH OTHER DUTIES. PROJECT LOCATION THE PROJECT WILL BE UNDERTAKEN IN THE CENTRAL ARKANSAS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR) COMPLEX ON HOLLA BEND, CACHE RIVER, AND BALD KNOB NWRS IN ARKANSAS. HOUSING WILL BE PROVIDED ON CACHE RIVER NWR NEAR COTTON PLANT, AR.

MATHEWS BRAKE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR) IS MAINTAINED AS A WETLAND COMPLEX PRIMARILY COMPOSED OF FORESTED, AQUATIC BED, AND OPEN WATER WETLANDS. MATHEWS BRAKE NWR HISTORICALLY WAS SUBJECTED TO PERIODIC DRAWDOWNS TO CONSOLIDATE SEDIMENTS, CONTROL INVASIVE SPECIES, AND ALLOW MANAGEMENT ACTIVITIES TO BENEFIT RESOURCES OF CONCERN, SUCH AS WATERFOWL, MARSH BIRDS, AND OTHER WATERBIRDS. FOLLOWING MAJOR HYDROLOGICAL CHANGES AND STABILIZATION OF THE HYDROPERIOD SINCE THE EARLY 2000S, PARTNERS COMPLETED INSTALLATION OF A WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE IN 2016 TO RESTORE HYDROLOGICAL VARIABILITY AND MANAGEMENT CAPACITY. UNFORTUNATELY, SEVERAL INVASIVE (WATER HYACINTH) AND UNDESIRABLE (AMERICAN WATER LOTUS) SPECIES ESTABLISHED DURING THE INTERIM AND HAVE SIGNIFICANTLY DEGRADED THE BRAKE FOR PRIORITY RESOURCES OF CONCERN AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES. IN 2015, MATHEWS BRAKE NWR STAFF BEGAN INTENSIVE MANAGEMENT EFFORTS TO CONTROL INVASIVE VEGETATION AND THOSE EFFORTS HAVE RECENTLY INTENSIFIED WITH INCREASED REGIONAL-OFFICE SUPPORTED PLANNING AND FUNDING. WE ARE CURRENTLY WORKING ON A WATER MANAGEMENT   INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT PLAN TO FACILITATE LARGE MANAGEMENT CHANGES THAT WILL HELP RESTORE HISTORICAL HYDROLOGY, INCREASE WETLAND QUALITY FOR PRIORITY WILDLIFE, AND CONTROL INVASIVE AQUATIC SPECIES. THIS REMOTE CLASSIFICATION MODEL CURRENTLY BEING DEVELOPED FOR BIG LAKE NWR CAN BE USED TO ADDRESS THOSE MONITORING NEEDS AS WELL AS PROVIDE A RAPID AND PRACTICAL METHOD FOR MONITORING VEGETATION CONDITIONS ANNUALLY AS MANAGEMENT PRACTICES OCCUR. THIS PROJECT IS AN EXCELLENT OPPORTUNITY TO SUPPORT ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT USING NEW TECHNOLOGY, PARTNERSHIPS, AND LEVERAGE. THIS PROJECT WILL 1) VALIDATE THE UTILITY OF A NEWLY DEVELOPED VEGETATION CLASSIFICATION MODEL FROM BIG LAKE NWR FOR MONITORING VEGETATION CHANGES DURING SUMMERFALL 20212023 AS A RESULT OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS ON MATHEWS BRAKE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, 2) ESTIMATE ENERGETIC CARRYING CAPACITY FOR WATERFOWL USING REMOTE SENSING MODEL-BASED VEGETATION CLASSIFICATIONS FOR COMPARISON WITH ENERGY DEMAND ESTIMATED THROUGH USE DAYS FROM AERIAL SURVEYS DURING WINTER 20222024 AT MATHEWS BRAKE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, AND 3) OPERATIONALIZE A RAPID, REMOTE-SENSING BASED AQUATIC VEGETATION CLASSIFICATION MODEL TO SUPPORT MONITORING OF MANAGEMENT ACTIONS IN THE FUTURE TO CONTROL INVASIVE AQUATIC PLANTS AND ENCOURAGE MORE DESIRABLE PLANT COMMUNITIES FOR WATERFOWL, MARSH BIRDS, AND OTHER WATERBIRDS AT MATHEWS BRAKE AND OTHER SIMILAR NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES.

THE DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR FIREFIGHTING BUREAUS UTILIZE BURNED AREA REHABILITATION PROJECTS TO ADDRESS THE DAMAGING EFFECTS OF WILDFIRE ON SERVICE LANDS. BURNED AREA REHABILITATION BEGINS WITHIN FIVE YEARS OF A WILDFIRE CONTAINMENT IN ORDER TO REPAIR OR IMPROVE FIRE-DAMAGED LANDS THAT ARE UNLIKELY TO NATURALLY RECOVER TO MANAGEMENT APPROVED CONDITIONS. THE ARIZONA FIRE ZONE HAS SEVERAL RESTORATION PROJECTS ON-GOING TO ADDRESS THE ECOLOGICAL IMPACTS OF THE AVONDALE AND PLANET RANCH FIRES. THE AGREEMENT PARTNER, THE ALTAR VALLEY CONSERVATION ALLIANCE, WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ANALYZING, TREATING, RE-PLANTING AND MAINTAINING BURN SCARS TO ENSURE VITAL THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES HABITAT IS PROTECTED. RESTORATION WORK WILL INCLUDE, BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO, THE REMOVAL OF BURNED OR CHARRED INVASIVE SPECIES TIMBER AND DEBRIS, CLEARING WATER BODIES, RIVERS AND STREAMS OF DOWN AND DEAD WOOD, SOIL PREPARATION, PLANTING OF NATIVE SPECIES INCLUDING IMPORTANT RIPARIAN PLANTS LIKE FREMONT WILLOW AND GODDINGS COTTONWOOD AS WELL AS UPLAND MESQUITE, SALT BUSH, QUAIL BUSH, BRITTLEBUSH AND OTHER FORBS AND GRASSES, EROSION CONTROL METHODS INCLUDING ONE ROCK DAMS, WATTLES AND OTHER WATER DIVERSION AND CONTROL STRUCTURES, IRRIGATION OF PLANTINGS AND MONITORING EFFORTS TO RECORD RESULTS AND FACILITATE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT. WITHOUT THE CRITICAL EFFORTS OF ALTAR VALLEY CONSERVATION ALLIANCE STAFF, IMPORTANT HABITAT ON U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE LANDS FOR MIGRATORY BIRD SPECIES LIKE THE YELLOW BILLED CUCKOO, ENDEMIC SPECIES LIKE THE WILLOW FLYCATCHER AND RIDGEWAYS AND BLACK RAILS, MEXICAN GARTER SNAKE, CHIRICAHUA LEOPARD FROGS AND OTHERS WILL EXPERIENCE A LOSS OF SHRINKING HABITAT.

THE FORESTED HABITATS DOMINATING US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) REFUGES IN THE NORTHEASTERN US HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED AS HIGH RISK TO TREE MORTALITY AND OTHER CHANGES DUE TO CLIMATE EXTREMES, LIKE DROUGHT, AS WELL AS INCREASES IN DISTURBANCES (WIND, ICE, FIRE) AND INVASIVE INSECTS AND DISEASES. THESE IMPACTS GREATLY THREATEN THE MULTITUDE OF VALUES FORESTS IN THESE AREAS PROVIDE, INCLUDING HABITAT FOR PRIORITY WILDLIFE SPECIES AND NUMEROUS CULTURAL AND ECOLOGICAL VALUES. TO ADDRESS THESE IMPACTS, THERE IS A GREAT NEED FOR TOOLS AND APPROACHES FOR SUSTAINING NORTHEASTERN FORESTS INTO THE FUTURE, DESPITE THE MANY NOVEL FACTORS NOW THREATENING THEM.RESEARCHERS AND ADAPTATION SPECIALISTS ARE EXAMINING USFWS REFUGES IN THE NORTHERN FOREST REGION TO GENERATE FINE SCALE, LOCAL VULNERABILITY ASSESSMENTS THAT DETERMINE WHICH FOREST HABITATS IN THESE REFUGES ARE MOST VULNERABLE TO CHANGING CLIMATE AND DISTURBANCE REGIMES. THIS WORK WILL OUTLINE CLIMATE-INFORMED FOREST ADAPTATION STRATEGIES THAT BEST INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF THESE FORESTS TO PROJECTED CHANGES WITH AREAS IDENTIFIED ON EACH REFUGE FOR PRIORITIZING THE APPLICATION OF THESE STRATEGIES TO INCREASE RESILIENCE. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL INCREASE THE TRACKING OF FOREST VULNERABILITY OVER TIME, AS WELL AS THE ABILITY OF ADAPTATION PRACTICES TO INCREASE RESILIENCE BY DEVELOPING INVENTORY AND MONITORING PROTOCOLS FOR EXAMINING CHANGES IN FOREST HABITATS AT EACH REFUGE. GIVEN THE IMPORTANCE OF FORESTS TO SUPPORTING THE WILDLIFE AND OTHER VALUES THESE REFUGES PROVIDE, FINDING WAYS TO INCREASE THE RESILIENCE OF THESE AREAS TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND OTHER NOVEL IMPACTS WILL BE INCREASINGLY CRITICAL INTO THE FUTURE.

USING BIGHORN SHEEP GPS DATA (49 SHEEP SINCE JANUARY 2019) COLLECTED BY HART MOUNTAIN REFUGE STAFF AND STATE AGENCY COLLABORATORS, AND AVAILABLE GIS LAYERS WHICH INCLUDES INFORMATION ABOUT HABITAT CHANGES (FIRE HISTORY INCLUDING INTENSITY INFORMATION, JUNIPER REMOVAL, INVASIVE SPECIES SPRAYING, NATIVE VEGETATION RESEEDING, AND NAIP IMAGERY), WE WILL DEVELOP A RESOURCE SELECTION FUNCTION (RSF) OR RESOURCE UTILIZATION FUNCTION (RUF) TYPE ANALYSIS THAT WOULD AID IN MANAGEMENT EFFORTS. BOTH RUF AND RSF TYPE ANALYSES WOULD INVOLVE USE OF GIS LAYERS AND SHEEP LOCATIONS, ARE STANDARD, COMPARABLE METHODS, AND ARE WELL ACCEPTED IN THE PUBLISHED LITERATURE. THE FINAL CHOICE AMONG SPECIFIC ANALYTICAL METHODS WILL DEPEND ON FEATURES OF THE SHEEP LOCATION AND GIS DATASETS ONCE PROVIDED BY COLLABORATORS. THESE ANALYSES JOIN LOCATION DATA, EITHER EACH LOCATION OR THE ASSOCIATED UTILIZATION DISTRIBUTION, WITH UNDERLYING GIS DATA TO DETERMINE WHICH RESOURCES ARE SELECTED AND AVOIDED, THE STRENGTH OF SELECTION, AND THE PREDICTED RELATIVE PROBABILITY OF SHEEP USE ON THE LANDSCAPE. THIS ANALYSIS WILL PROVIDE INFORMATION ABOUT SHEEP RESPONSE TO HABITAT CHANGES AND CAN BE TEMPORALLY SCALED VARIOUS WAYS (MONTHLY, SEASONALLY, ANNUALLY) TO DEMONSTRATE SHIFTS IN HABITAT SELECTION OVER TIME. THE OUTPUT OF THIS ANALYSIS WOULD BE PROVIDED IN A WRITTEN REPORT AND ACCOMPANYING GIS LAYERS.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) IS LAUNCHING THE TREASURE VALLEY URBAN CONSERVATION PARTNERSHIP (TVUCP) AS PART OF THE SERVICES NATIONAL URBAN WILDLIFE CONSERVATION PROGRAM, WITH A PRIMARY GOAL OF EXPANDING ACCESS TO GREEN SPACE, EDUCATION AND OUTDOOR RECREATION FOR AMERICANS LIVING IN AND AROUND CITIES. THIS PROJECT CENTERS THE IDEA THAT BUILDING STRONG, MEANINGFUL RELATIONSHIPS WITH DIVERSE COMMUNITIES IS KEY TO ACHIEVING EQUITABLE CONSERVATION OUTCOMES.  FRIENDS OF DEER FLAT WILDLIFE REFUGE ARE UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO SUPPORT THE LAUNCH OF THE TVUCP TO CREATE A STRONG FOUNDATION FOR THE SERVICE, FRIENDS, AND PARTNERS TO SERVE THE GREATER TREASURE VALLEY COMMUNITY.SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES INCLUDE: 1) INSPIRE AND CULTIVATE MEANINGFUL CONNECTION TO NATURAL ENVIRONMENTS AND REDUCE BARRIERS TO OUTDOOR RECREATION AMONG DIVERSE POPULATIONS IN THE TREASURE VALLEY  2) AMPLIFY THE COLLECTIVE EFFORTS OF LOCAL COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS TO INCREASE DEPTH AND BREADTH OF ENGAGEMENT WITH AN INCREASINGLY DIVERSE COMMUNITY  3) IMPROVE THE CAPACITY FOR LOCAL EDUCATORS, FWS STAFF, VOLUNTEERS, AND OTHER KEY PARTNERS TO INCORPORATE BEST PRACTICES IN ENGAGING WITH COMMUNITIES  AND 4) DEVELOP SYSTEMATIC GUIDANCE TO CARRY THE PROGRAM INTO THE FUTURE.

THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT BETWEEN US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND RUFFED GROUSE SOCIETY   AMERICAN WOODCOCK SOCIETY WILL ENHANCE FOREST HABITAT AND RECREATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES ON THE 258-ACRE WESTVILLE UNIT OF THE MISSISQUOI NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. IN FY 2024, WE WILL WORK TOGETHER TO DEVELOP A HABITAT MANAGEMENT PLAN THAT WILL GUIDE FUTURE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR WILDLIFE HABITAT ENHANCEMENTS, CREATE A 2-3 VEHICLE PARKING AREA (GRAVEL) AT A SITE MUTUALLY AGREED UPON TO IMPROVE RECREATIONAL ACCESS TO THE PROPERTY AND IMPLEMENT 2-3 ACRES OF WILDLIFE PATCH CUTS AS AN INITIATION OF THE HABITAT WORK GUIDED BY THE MANAGEMENT PLAN.

THE CONVERSATION FUND PROPOSES TO WORK WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE S CHESAPEAKE MARSHLANDS NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE COMPLEX AND SELECTED TECHNICAL  EXPERTS TO DESIGN, PLAN IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE ONE OR MORE OF THE MARSH RESTORATION STRATEGIES DESCRIBED IN BLACKWATER 2100: A STRATEGY FOR SALT MARSH PERSISTENCE IN AN ERA OF CLIMATE CHANGE (J.A. LERNER ET AL., THE CONSERVATION FUND 2013). THE CONSERVATION FUND AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HAVE COLLABORATED ON MULTIPLE PROJECTS TO RESTORE TIDAL MARSHES WITHIN BLACKWATER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE.  THIS PROJECT PROPOSES TO USE THE CONSERVATION FUND AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE EXPERTISE COMBINED WITH AN EXPERT ADVISORY PANEL TO IDENTIFY THE LOCATIONS AND TYPES OF PROJECTS THAT BEST ALIGN WITH THE REFUGE WILDLIFE HABITAT NEEDS AND MAXIMIZE AVAILABLE FUNDING. FOLLOWING PLANNING AND DESIGN, IMPLEMENTATION IS ANTICIPATED FOR 2024 - 2025 FOR ONE OR MORE MAJOR PROJECTS. IMPLEMENTATION MAY CONTINUE INTO 2025 - 2026, AND MONITORING AND EVALUATION OF IMPLEMENTED RESTORATION PROJECTS WILL TAKE PLACE PRIMARILY IN 2017 - 2018 WORK. MARSH RESTORATION AND RESILIENCE STRATEGIES AND IMPLEMENTATION TECHNIQUES USED AT BLACKWATER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE ARE CENTRAL TO THE LONG-TERM PLANS OF THE MULTI-AGENCY AND ORGANIZATION DELMARVA RESTORATION AND CONSERVATION NETWORK.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INTEGRATE TARGETED HAZARDOUS FUELS REDUCTION ACTIVITIES WITH ONGOING WORK TO IMPLEMENT THE SOUTH WILLAPA BAY CONSERVATION AREA FOREST LANDSCAPE RESTORATION PLAN. THE EXPECTED OUTCOME OF THIS 5-YEAR PROJECT IS A REDUCTION IN THE AMOUNT OF HAZARDOUS FUELS AND IMPLEMENTATION OF FOREST RESTORATION TREATMENTS IN WILLAPA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (REFUGE) FORESTS IN ORDER TO 1) REDUCE THE RISK OF CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE ON THE REFUGE AND SURROUNDING AREA, 2) IMPROVE ACCESS TO REFUGE FOREST STANDS FOR WILDFIRE RESPONSE, AND 3) RESTORE ECOLOGICAL FUNCTION OF FOREST HABITATS BY IMPROVING FOREST STAND STRUCTURE AND COMPLEXITY FOR THE ENHANCEMENT OF HABITAT CRITICAL TO THE FEDERALLY THREATENED MARBLED MURRELET AND OTHER LATE SUCCESSIONAL DEPENDENT WILDLIFE SPECIES, 4) INCREASE FOREST HEALTH AND CLIMATE RESILIENCY 5) MAINTAIN CONSISTENCY WITH OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE FOREST LANDSCAPE RESTORATION PLAN AND REFUGE COMPREHENSIVE CONSERVATION PLAN.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP AN APPROACH TO MONITORING THE EXTENT OF WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER (WSP) NESTING HABITAT AT GUADALUPE-NIPOMO DUNES NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (REFUGE). PROJECT OBJECTIVES ARE THE FOLLOWING: 1. DEVELOP A HABITAT SUITABILITY MODEL (HSU) TO EVALUATE THE EXTENT OF WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER (WSP) NESTING HABITAT AT GUADALUPE-NIPOMO DUNES NWR USING PHYSICAL ENVIRONMENTAL AND LOCAL SUBSTRATE VARIABLES SUCH AS VEGETATION AND WRACK COVER THAT CAN BE CONTROLLED THROUGH MANAGEMENT ACTION  2. DEVELOP A SURVEY PROTOCOL FOR MONITORING CHANGE IN THE EXTENT OF WSP NESTING HABITAT ON THE REFUGE OVER TIME (INFORMED BY THE HSU) THAT MEETS USFWS PROTOCOL STANDARDS. THE PROTOCOL WILL BE DESIGNED TO EVALUATE THE PROGRESS IN ACHIEVING A REFUGE MANAGEMENT OBJECTIVE FOCUSED ON THE EXTENT OF WESTERN SNOWY PLOVER NESTING HABITAT. THE OBJECTIVE WAS DEVELOPED DURING THE REFUGE ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT PROJECT (RAMP, KNOWN NATIONALLY AS THE CHIEFS CHALLENGE) AND THE INFORMATION GATHERED DURING THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED TO EVALUATE AND UPDATE THIS OBJECTIVE. THIS WORK WILL HELP THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) EVALUATE AND IMPROVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES AIMED AT IMPROVING WSP HABITAT AT THE REFUGE.

THE SERVICE WILL PROVIDE FUNDS IN SUPPORT OF PARTNERSHIP WITH DU FOR TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN IMPLEMENTATION OF WETLAND AND GRASSLAND ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION PROJECTS IN THE PPR OF NORTH DAKOTA, SOUTH DAKOTA, AND MONTANA. ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION ACTIVITIES WILL OCCUR ON WPA, CONSERVATION EASEMENTS, REFUGES, AND STATE WILDLIFE MANAGEMENT AREAS WITHIN THAT GEOGRAPHIC AREA. THE SERVICE WILL PROVIDE SPECIFIC GUIDELINES FOR EACH PROJECT AND DU WILL SUPPORT PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION THROUGH TECHNICAL SUPPORT AND ON-THE-GROUND RESTORATION WORK. COLLECTIVELY, THESE PROJECTS ARE INTENDED TO RESTORE AND IMPROVE CRITICALLY IMPORTANT BREEDING AREAS FOR GRASSLAND BIRDS, WATERFOWL, POLLINATORS, AND THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES. ADDITIONALLY, ENHANCEMENT AND RESTORATION EFFORTS WILL PROVIDE SUSTAINABLE PROPERTIES INCLUDING SOCIETAL BENEFITS OF FLOOD RESILIENCE, WATER QUALITY IMPROVEMENT, AND CARBON SEQUESTRATION.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) WILL MITIGATE PHYSICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS FROM ADITS, SHAFTS, AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTAMINATION THAT REMAIN AT ABANDONED MINE SITES ON NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES (NWR), AND RESTORE VEGETATION FOR THE BENEFIT OF EMPLOYEES, THE VISITING PUBLIC, AND WILDLIFE. THIS WORK WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED WITH FUNDING FROM THE BIPARTISAN INFRASTRUCTURE LAW, WHICH INCLUDES PROVISIONS TO RESTORE NATIVE VEGETATION AND MITIGATE PHYSICAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL HAZARDS ON MINED LAND ON FEDERAL LANDS. WITH THESE PROJECTS, THE SERVICE WILL IDENTIFY ABANDONED MINE LOCATIONS, ASSESS REMAINING HAZARDS, IMPLEMENT MITIGATION MEASURES WHERE NEEDED TO REDUCE ANY REMAINING RISK TO HUMAN HEALTH AND THE ENVIRONMENT, AND RESTORE NATIVE VEGETATION IN A MANNER THAT IS PROTECTIVE OF BATS AND OTHER WILDLIFE.

MT. ADAMS RESOURCE STEWARDS WILL INSTALL A CONTINUOUS FOREST INVENTORY (CFI) AT A 5-ACRE INTENSITY ACROSS APPROXIMATELY 2,000 ACRES OF UPLAND AND FORESTED PORTIONS OF CONBOY LAKE NWR IN ORDER TO TRACK LONG TERM CHANGES IN FOREST CONDITIONS AS A RESULT OF FOREST TREATMENTS DESIGNED TO ENHANCE HABITAT AND FOREST RESILIENCY. DATA FROM THIS EFFORT WILL SUPPORT UPDATES TO THE REFUGE FOREST MANAGEMENT PLAN AND INFORM ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES.

PHEASANTS FOREVER, INC. (PF), WILL WORK COOPERATIVELY WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) WITHIN THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE REGION (PPR, FIGURE 1) OF MINNESOTA AND IOWA TO EVALUATE AND RESTORE NATIVE GRASSLANDS AND WETLANDS ON EXISTING NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR) SYSTEM LANDS THROUGH THE HIRING OF EIGHT FIELD BIOLOGISTS. THESE POSITIONS WILL HELP ADDRESS CLIMATE CHANGE AS IT PERTAINS TO MAKING SERVICE PROPERTIES MORE RESILIENT TO CLIMATE CHANGE AND INCREASING CARBON SEQUESTRATION.THE MISSION OF PF IS TO CONSERVE PHEASANTS, QUAIL, AND OTHER WILDLIFE THROUGH HABITAT IMPROVEMENTS, PUBLIC ACCESS, EDUCATION, AND CONSERVATION ADVOCACY. PHEASANTS FOREVER HAS DEMONSTRATED SUCCESS ON SEVERAL LARGE-SCALE PROJECTS WITH THE SERVICE IN PREVIOUS YEARS, MAKING PF IDEALLY SITUATED TO TACKLE THE NATURE BASED SOLUTIONS EFFORT.

ENVIRONMENTAL DNA (EDNA) IS DNA SHED BY LIVING ORGANISMS INTO THE ENVIRONMENT THROUGH SLOUGHED SKIN OR SCALES, MUCUS, FECES, OR URINE. QUANTITATIVE PCR (QPCR), HIGH THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING, OR CRISPR BASED TECHNIQUES CAN DETECT EDNA IN ENVIRONMENTAL SAMPLES, ALLOWING BIOLOGISTS TO DETERMINE THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF A SPECIES AT A SAMPLING LOCATION WITHOUT HAVING TO DIRECTLY OBSERVE OR CAPTURE ORGANISMS. EDNA DETECTION EXPLOITS DNA BARCODES, OR GENE REGIONS THAT VARY BETWEEN TAXA, AND CAN TARGET SINGLE SPECIES OR MULTIPLE SPECIES. SINGLE SPECIES DETECTION, WHICH IS USEFUL WHEN ONLY ONE OR A SMALL NUMBER OF SPECIES ARE TARGETED, INVOLVES AMPLIFICATION OF A SPECIES-SPECIFIC SEQUENCE ON A QPCR MACHINE OR A HANDHELD FLUORESCENCE READER. MULTI-SPECIES DETECTION, ALSO KNOWN AS EDNA METABARCODING, USES UNIVERSAL PRIMERS TO AMPLIFY ONE OR MORE BARCODING REGIONS FOR ALL DNA IN A SAMPLE. THESE AMPLIFIED REGIONS THEN UNDERGO HIGH THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING AND ARE SORTED BIOINFORMATICALLY. EDNA METABARCODING CAN PROVIDE COMMUNITY-LEVEL INVENTORIES OF SAMPLING LOCATIONS (LIM ET AL. 2016  PORT ET AL. 2016) WHICH CAN BE USEFUL FOR MANAGING ECOSYSTEMS WHERE BIODIVERSITY IS POORLY CHARACTERIZED.UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WE PROPOSE TO COMPLETE THE THIRD PHASE IN DEVELOPING EDNA BASED APPROACHES FOR NON-INVASIVE MONITORING OF CALIFORNIA VERNAL POOL ECOSYSTEMS. WE WILL USE THE REFERENCE SEQUENCE DATABASE DEVELOPED IN PHASE I OF THIS PROJECT TO BEGIN ASSESSING VERNAL POOL BIODIVERSITY. WE WILL CONTINUE SAMPLING EDNA FROM 4-6 POOLS IN EACH OF FOUR VERNAL POOL COMPLEXES: KERN NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR), PIXLEY NWR, STONE LAKES NWR, AND DON EDWARDS SAN FRANCISCO BAY NWR (TATE-MONTENEGRO AND SCHREIER 2023). WE WILL PERFORM EDNA METABARCODING FOR USING LOCI SELECTED IN PHASE I BEST ABLE TO IDENTIFY VERNAL POOL INVERTEBRATES, AMPHIBIANS, AND PLANTS OF GREATEST INTEREST TO REFUGE MANAGERS. WE WILL COMPARE THE ABILITY OF EDNA METABARCODING TO NON-INVASIVELY DETECT TARGET TAXA TO CURRENT FIELD METHODS (E.G. DIP-NETTING). WE WILL ALSO USE EDNA METABARCODING TO COMPARE BIODIVERSITY BETWEEN NATURAL AND MITIGATED VERNAL POOLS AT ONE OR MORE REFUGES. THE DESIGN OF SHERLOCK ASSAYS FOR LISTED THREATENED AND ENDANGERED VERNAL POOLS SPECIES WILL BEGIN IN THIS PHASE. SHERLOCK ASSAYS WILL ALLOW FOR RAPID (30 MINS OR LESS  BAERWALD ET AL. 2020, 2023) DETECTION OF TARGET SPECIES FROM AN EDNA SAMPLE TAKEN IN THE FIELD WITHOUT THE NEED FOR MOLECULAR EXPERTISE OR EXPENSIVE INSTRUMENTATION. BELOW WE DESCRIBE HOW WE PLAN TO ACCOMPLISH THIS THIRD PHASE.

RESTORE THE FIRST CREEK RIPARIAN CORRIDOR TO PROVIDE CONSISTENT ACCESS TO WATER ( 1.5M): FIRST CREEK IS AN IMPORTANT WATER SOURCE FOR THE REFUGES BISON HERD. NEARLY A CENTURY AGO, THE CREEK WAS HEAVILY ALTERED AND CHANNELIZED. REFUGE STAFF WOULD RESTORE NATURAL HYDROLOGY AND FLOODPLAIN ACTIVITIES ALONG FIRST CREEK, ALLOWING A RETURN TO NATURAL WATER FLOWS AND MORE CONSISTENT WATER ACCESS FOR BISON THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. A CONCEPTUAL PLAN FOR RESTORATION WAS CREATED IN 1994 AND THE SERVICE HAS COMPLETED A SMALL PORTION OF THIS RESTORATION. THIS PROJECT WOULD INCLUDE INSTALLATION OF ADDITIONAL DROP STRUCTURES AND RESTORATION OF COTTONWOOD AND WILLOWS THROUGHOUT THE DRAINAGE AREA. TO SUPPORT THIS RESTORATION,  1.5 MILLION WOULD BE REQUIRED FOR BOTH CONTRACT AND SERVICE STAFF WORK TO RESTORE ANOTHER 1.5 MILES OF THE FIRST CREEK CORRIDOR WITHIN THE REFUGE.  PORTIONS OF THIS PROJECT, ESPECIALLY REPLACEMENT OF DAMAGED CULVERTS AND ROAD CROSSINGS, ARE INCLUDED IN DEFERRED MAINTENANCE FUNDING.

WITHIN THIS AREA BOTH THE US FISH   WILDLIFE SERVICE USFWS AND THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES DNR OWN AND MANAGE PROPERTY WITH THE GOAL OF PRODUCING EXCELLENT WATERFOWL AND MIGRATORY BIRD PRODUCTION HABITAT.IOWA DNR, ACTING ON BEHALF OF USFWS, WILL PERFORM THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF REPAIRING AND ENHANCING WETLAND BASINS ON TEN WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREAS IN THE PRAIRIE POTHOLE JOINT VENTURE PRIORITY COMPLEXES, AND SEEDING A NEWLY ACQUIRED WPA FROM CROPLAND TO A DIVERSE PRAIRIE SEEDING.THE SERVICE AND DEPARTMENT WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR OVERSITE, PLAN DEVELOPMENT, REVIEW, AND INSPECTION OF THE RESTORATION PROJECTS, ALONG WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF LONG RANGE MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR THE RESTORED WETLAND COMPLEXES. NOXIOUS WEEDS AND INVASIVE PLANTS ARE A MAJOR THREAT TO NATIVE ECOSYSTEMS, AND WEED   INVASIVE PLANT SURVEYS, MAPPING, AND TREATMENTS ARE AN INTEGRAL PART OF LAND MANAGEMENT. AS SUCH, GREAT BASIN INSTITUTE (GBI), IN COOPERATION WITH THE US FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), WILL PROVIDE ONE INVASIVE SPECIES TECHNICIAN TO SUPPORT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES AT DESERT NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR). ACTIVITIES RANGE FROM MECHANICAL OR CHEMICAL TREATMENT OF INVASIVE WEEDS TO DATA MANAGEMENT AND ENTRY TO OVERSEEING COMMUNITY VOLUNTEERS ENGAGED IN RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ON THE REFUGE. ALL COMBINED, THESE EFFORTS WILL BENEFIT WILDLIFE AND PROVIDE THE PUBLIC A LITERAL REFUGE TO ENJOY TRANQUILITY, VIEW WILDLIFE, AND OTHERWISE ENJOY THEIR PUBLIC LANDS. REMOVING INVASIVES CAN ALSO HAVE THE ANCILLARY BENEFITS OF REDUCING RISKS FROM FLOODING AND WILDFIRE.

THE ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF SAN DIEGO IS DEDICATED TO PARTNERING WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO SUPPORT SCIENCE TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS FOR THE BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE AND WILD PLACES. THROUGH THE PROPOSED PROGRAM, WE WILL PROVIDE FREE SCIENCE-BASED LABORATORY AND FIELD RESEARCH EXPERIENCES TO 18 SCIENCE TEACHERS AND APPROXIMATELY 576 STUDENTS FROM TITLE I-ELIGIBLE SCHOOLS ACROSS SAN DIEGO AND LOS ANGELES COUNTIES. SELECTED SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA SCIENCE TEACHERS WILL FIRST ENGAGE WITH OUR TEACHER WORKSHOPS IN CONSERVATION SCIENCE WHICH ARE DESIGNED TO: (1) PROVIDE REPLICABLE, RELEVANT, STANDARDS-BASED CONSERVATION SCIENCE ACTIVITIES FOR FORMAL AND INFORMAL EDUCATION SETTINGS, (2) CONNECT SCIENCE EDUCATORS TO WILDLIFE CONSERVATION THROUGH LABORATORY AND FIELD-BASED EXPERIENCES THAT SHARE RECENT ADVANCES IN CONSERVATION RESEARCH, AND (3) PROVIDE A FORUM FOR SCIENCE EDUCATORS TO NETWORK AND SHARE IDEAS FOR WEAVING CONSERVATION THEMES INTO THEIR SCHOOL COMMUNITY AND ENGAGING STUDENTS IN CONSERVATION. THE WORKSHOP CURRICULUM ADDRESSES A WIDE RANGE OF TOPICS FROM A MULTITUDE OF SCIENTIFIC DISCIPLINES INCLUDING SPATIAL ECOLOGY, RESTORATION AND REINTRODUCTION BIOLOGY, GENETIC RECOVERY, REPRODUCTIVE ENDOCRINOLOGY, GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE, AND THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF CONSERVATION. IT ALSO INCLUDES A GROUP PROJECT THAT ENGAGES TEACHERS IN THE PROCESS OF OPEN INQUIRY AND TEACHES THEM HOW TO GUIDE THIS IMPORTANT PROCESS WITH THEIR STUDENTS. AS PART OF THE PROJECT, PARTICIPANTS MAKE SCIENTIFIC OBSERVATIONS AT THE SAN DIEGO ZOO SAFARI PARK, DEVELOP COMPARATIVE QUESTIONS, DEVISE INVESTIGATIONS TO ANSWER THEIR QUESTIONS, AND COMMUNICATE THEIR RESULTS TO THE COHORT. TO EXTEND THE WORKSHOP EXPERIENCE DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS, WE WILL INVITE WORKSHOP ALUMNI AND THEIR STUDENTS (APPROXIMATELY 576 STUDENTS) TO ENGAGE WITH OUR OUTDOOR LEARNING LAB (OLL) AND ASSOCIATED LIFE IN A BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOT INTERACTIVE FIELD RESEARCH CURRICULUM, WHICH IS DESIGNED TO: (1) ENHANCE STUDENTS  INQUIRY AND CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS AS THEY DISCOVER AND MONITOR NATIVE SPECIES, (2) INCREASE THEIR INTEREST IN STEM CAREERS RELATED TO SPECIES RECOVERY, AND (3) ENHANCE THEIR APPRECIATION OF THEIR UNIQUE NATURAL HERITAGE AND HOW HUMAN ACTIVITIES IMPACT THE HEALTH AND COMPOSITION OF LOCAL ECOSYSTEMS. THE FIELD-BASED RESEARCH EXPERIENCE IN THE OUTDOOR LEARNING LAB WILL CONNECT STUDENTS TO NATURE AS THEY LEARN ABOUT AND OBSERVE THE NATIVE PLANTS AND ANIMALS THAT ARE PART OF THE CALIFORNIA FLORISTIC PROVINCE, OUR OWN LOCAL BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOT. STUDENTS WILL ENGAGE WITH RESOURCES THAT ENCOURAGE THEM TO CRITICALLY EVALUATE HOW HUMAN-MEDIATED CHANGE IN OUR ENVIRONMENT RELATES TO CHANGES IN FIRE REGIMES, WATER USAGE, AND ULTIMATELY LOSS OF LOCAL BIODIVERSITY IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA AND BEYOND, WITH THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF INSPIRING ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. THEY WILL ALSO VISIT THE SAFARI PARK TO OBSERVE ENDANGERED SPECIES AND CURRENT FIELD RESEARCH PROJECTS IN ACTION. OUR AIM IS NOT ONLY TO EXPAND PARTICIPATING TEACHERS  KNOWLEDGE ABOUT CONSERVATION SCIENCE THROUGH RELEVANT LAB AND FIELD-BASED EXPERIENCES, BUT ALSO TO PREPARE THEM FOR THE ROLE OF FACILITATOR IN THE OPEN INQUIRY PROCESS AND HOW TO EFFECTIVELY ENGAGE THEIR STUDENTS IN THE CREATION OF ORIGINAL QUESTIONS AND METHODS FOR ANSWERING THEM. WE WILL PROVIDE A MEANINGFUL AND RELEVANT CONTEXT FOR THE NGSS SO THAT OUR TEACHER PARTNERS NOT ONLY MEET THEIR CAMPUS DISTRICT REQUIREMENTS BUT ALSO FULFILL THEIR COMMITMENT TO FOSTERING THE NEXT GENERATION OF SCIENCE PROFESSIONALS.

THE TARGET AUDIENCE OF OUR WILDLIFE RANGERS PROGRAM IS FIFTH-GRADE STUDENTS ENROLLED AT SCHOOLS IN THE SOUTHERN HALF OF SAN DIEGO COUNTY THAT ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE TITLE I FUNDING. RESEARCH SHOWS THERE IS A DIRECT CORRELATION BETWEEN SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS AND ACCESS TO NATURE AND OUTDOOR SPACES--NAMELY THAT THE LOWER THE MEDIAN INCOME IN AN URBAN AREA, THE LESS LIKELY THAT STUDENTS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO NATURE. THROUGH THIS PROPOSED PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, THE ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY OF SAN DIEGO D B A SAN DIEGO ZOO WILDLIFE ALLIANCE WILL RESPOND TO THIS CHALLENGE BY CONNECTING FIFTH-GRADE STUDENTS FROM TITLE I SCHOOLS IN SOUTHERN SAN DIEGO COUNTY TO OUR NATIVE WILDERNESS THROUGH INTERACTIVE CLASSROOM PROGRAMMING AND IMMERSIVE FIELD TRIPS TO THE LOCAL MARSH HABITAT. OUR PROGRAM ALIGNS WITH THE GOALS OF THE SOCAL URBAN WILDLIFE REFUGE PROJECT BY ENGAGING STUDENTS IN CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES THAT PROMOTE IN THEM A CONCERN AND PASSION TO PROTECT THE NATURAL WORLD. WE WILL CONCENTRATE OUR RECRUITING EFFORTS IN THE DISTRICTS WITH THE HIGHEST PERCENTAGE OF STUDENTS ELIGIBLE FOR FREE AND REDUCED-PRICE MEALS, WHICH IS CORRELATED WITH HIGHER RATES OF POVERTY.

THROUGH RECREATIONAL LEARNING ACTIVITIES LIKE KAYAKING, MOUNTAIN BIKING, SURFING, HIKING, AND STEWARDSHIP, OUTDOOR OUTREACH WILL CREATE AN ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH PARTICIPANTS FEEL SAFE AND WELCOME, BOTH IN THE OUTDOORS AND SPECIFICALLY IN WILDLIFE REFUGES. BY FORGING AN AUTHENTIC CONNECTION BETWEEN URBAN YOUTH AND CLOSE-TO-HOME OPEN SPACE AREAS, OUTDOOR OUTREACH CAN PROVIDE STEPPING STONES OF ENGAGEMENT THAT INSPIRE YOUTH PARTICIPANTS TO VALUE, RESPECT, AND PROTECT THE PLACES WHERE THEY PLAY.

STATEMENT OF NEED: JAMES RIVER NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (JRNWR) IS A 4,700-ACRE PROPERTY LOCATED IN PRINCE GEORGE COUNTY, VIRGINIA COMPRISED OF PINE-DOMINATED, HARDWOOD AND FLOODPLAIN FOREST. HISTORICALLY, UNDER A NATURAL DISTURBANCE REGIME OF LIGHTNING-SET, LOW-SEVERITY FIRES, JRNWR ACREAGE WOULD HAVE BEEN DOMINATED BY WIDELY-SPACED, FIRE-TOLERANT LONGLEAF PINE INSTEAD OF THE DENSELY STOCKED, FIRE-INTOLERANT LOBLOLLY PINE STANDS CURRENTLY FOUND ON THE PROPERTY. JRNWR S DENSE LOBLOLLY STANDS LIMIT NATIVE PLANT AND ANIMAL DIVERSITY AND POSE A RISK TO SURROUNDING LANDOWNERS SHOULD STANDS CATCH FIRE DUE TO LIGHTNING OR HUMAN-SET FIRE UNDER EXTREME WEATHER CONDITIONS. REFUGE BIOLOGISTS HAVE CONCERN CONDITIONS FAVORING EXTREME WILDFIRE CONDITIONS, PARTICULARLY EXTENDED DROUGHTS, MAY BE ON THE RISE AS A RESULT OF CLIMATE CHANGE. INTENSE WILDFIRE RESULTING IN CANOPY MORTALITY COULD SET BACK DECADES OF HABITAT RESTORATION WORK ON THE REFUGE. IN ADDITION, TRAVEL OF FIRE OFF-REFUGE COULD LEAD TO SUBSTANTIAL LOSS OF PROPERTY VALUE ON SURROUNDING, PRIVATELY-OWNED PARCELS OF LAND. THE PATH TOWARDS A MORE FIRE-RESILIENT AND BIOLOGICALLY DIVERSE FOREST AT JRNWR REQUIRES SUBSTANTIAL THINNING OF LOBLOLLY STANDS TO REDUCE FUEL LOADING AND TO SET THE STAGE FOR FUTURE CONVERSION OF LOBLOLLY TO LONGLEAF PINE.FWS STAFF RECOGNIZE THE URGENT NEED TO ENGAGE PARTNERS TO MEET THE AGGRESSIVE CHALLENGE OF RESTORING 2,100 ACRES OF PINE SAVANNA HABITAT WITHIN A 4-YEAR PROJECT TIMEFRAME. THE NATURE CONSERVANCY (TNC) HAS OVER 25 YEARS OF EXPERIENCE IN RESTORATION AND MANAGEMENT OF PINE SAVANNA HABITAT IN SOUTHEAST VA AND AS A TRUSTED NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION CAN HELP FWS ACHIEVE DESIRED CONSERVATION OUTCOMES.GOALS AND OBJECTIVES: THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE THE THREAT OF CATASTROPHIC WILDFIRE ON 2,100 ACRES OF LOBLOLLY PINE-DOMINATED HABITAT ON JRNWR. KEY OBJECTIVES ARE TO 1) REDUCE THE EXISTING LOBLOLLY PINE CANOPY DENSITY TO STOCKING LEVELS IDENTIFIED BY FWS BIOLOGISTS  2) REDUCE THE ABUNDANCE OF SURFACE FUELS  3) INITIATE ESTABLISHMENT OF MORE FIRE-TOLERANT CANOPY TREE SPECIES  4) MAINTAIN AND WHERE POSSIBLE INCREASE THE ABUNDANCE OF NATIVE PLANTS  5) CREATE NEW OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE REFUGE VISITOR ENGAGEMENT.ACTIVITIES: ELEMENT 1 OF THE PROJECT WILL BE COMPLETION OF A TIMBER INVENTORY OF PROJECT AREA STANDS TO DETERMINE BASELINE CONDITIONS. ELEMENT 2 WILL INVOLVE TIMBER HARVESTING TO REDUCE CANOPY TREE DENSITY. ELEMENT 3 WILL INVOLVE PRESCRIBED FIRE. ALL PROJECT AREA STANDS WILL RECEIVE AT LEAST ONE BURN OVER THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT PERIOD AND   -900 ACRES WILL BE TREATED TWICE. IN ELEMENT 4, TO BEGIN TRANSITION OF JRNWR TO SOUTHERN PINE SAVANNA ECOSYSTEM, A DEMONSTRATION AREA WILL BE UNDERPLANTED WITH LONGLEAF PINE IN A HEAVILY THINNED PINE STAND. NATIVE GRASS AND WILDFLOWER SEED WILL BE SOWN IN PINE STANDS AND OTHER SELECT SITES TO ACCELERATE RESTORATION OF GROUNDCOVER DIVERSITY. FINALLY, ELEMENT 5 WILL INVOLVE INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL TO RESTRICT THE SPREAD OF VARIOUS NON-NATIVE SPECIES FROM ROADWAY SHOULDERS INTO THINNED STANDS.SOURCE OF FUNDS: A TOTAL OF  94,000 OF F23AS00103 REFUGE ENHANCEMENT NON-INFRASTRUCTURE GRANT FUNDING THROUGH THE BIPARTISAN INSRASTRUCTURE BILL (BIL) IS REQUESTED. BIL FUNDS WILL BE USED TO COMPLETE A TIMBER INVENTORY OF THE PROJECT AREA AND TO CONTRACT WITH A PROFESSIONAL FORESTER TO MONITOR TIMBER HARVESTING OPERATIONS. ADDITIONAL FUNDING TO COVER ELEMENTS 3-5 WILL BE AVAILABLE THROUGH PROGRAM INCOME GENERATED FROM TIMBER HARVESTS. THE ESTIMATED TIMBER HARVEST INCOME OVER THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT IS  1,150,000.TIMELINE: THIS IS A 4-YEAR PROJECT BEGINNING SUMMER FALL 2023.

SHARING OUR SHORES: SOUTH BAY EDUCATION PROGRAMS ENGAGE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STUDENTS THROUGH IN-CLASS LESSONS AND FIELD TRIPS TO THE SAN DIEGO BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE TO TEACH STUDENTS ABOUT THE BIOLOGY AND THREATS TO BIRDS THAT UTILIZE SAN DIEGO BAY AS THEIR NESTING OR MIGRATORY RESTING LOCATIONS. EACH CLASS PARTICIPATES IN TWO FIELD TRIPS TO THE BAYSIDE BIRDING AND WALKING TRAIL IN IMPERIAL BEACH WHERE STUDENTS ARE ABLE TO SEE FIRST-HAND THE SHOREBIRDS IN THEIR NATURAL HABITATS AND CONTRIBUTE TO RESTORATION EFFORTS TO TRANSFORM THE BARREN LANDSCAPE INTO RICH WILDLIFE HABITAT. STUDENTS WILL ALSO EDUCATE VISITORS TO THE BAYSIDE BIRDING AND WALKING TRAIL BY CREATING CONSERVATION THEMED SIGNS THAT ARE INSTALLED AT THE REFUGE AND EDUCATE GUESTS ON WAYS TO PROTECT LOCAL AND MIGRATORY BIRDS. SAN DIEGO AUDUBON WILL PROVIDE FIFTEEN SHARING OUR SHORES PROGRAMS TO SOUTH BAY YOUTH, PROVIDING NEARLY 1,000 STUDENT VISITS TO NATURE.SAN DIEGO AUDUBON STAFF WILL ALSO PREPARE THE STUDENT PLANTING SITES AND MAINTAIN THE SITE FOR THE STUDENTS AND WILDLIFE THROUGH THE YEAR. WE WILL WEED, WATER, AND REPLACE PLANTS WHEN NEEDED, AND WE WILL ADD PLANTS TO THE HALOPHYTIC AREAS OF THE WESTERN EDGES OF THE PROJECT AREAS. WE WILL SHARE THIS WORK WITH THE BAYSIDE BIRDING AND WALKING TRAIL USERS THROUGH SHARED EBIRD LISTS, LOTERIAS AND SIGNS.THROUGH THESE EFFORTS, SAN DIEGO AUDUBON AIMS TO ENGAGE NOT ONLY THE STUDENTS OF OUR PROGRAMS, BUT THE ENTIRE COMMUNITY THROUGH OUTREACH AND RESTORATION EVENTS. BY IMPROVING THE LANDSCAPE TO BENEFIT BOTH HUMANS AND WILDLIFE, WE CAN ENSURE THAT THE NEXT GENERATION OF SAN DIEGIANS WILL GROW UP WITH AN APPRECIATION AND RESPECT FOR OUR LOCAL NATURE SPACES.

ELDRIDGE MARSH IS EXPERIENCING SIGNIFICANT DETERIORATION IN WILDLIFE HABITAT QUALITY AND QUANTITY. FAILING HISTORIC MARSH ALTERATIONS AND RISING SEA-LEVELS ARE TWO FORCES THAT HAVE LED TO THE LOSS OF VEGETATION AND CREATION OF AREAS OF SHALLOW STANDING WATER. THIS CONVERSION FROM VEGETATED SALT MARSH TO MUDFLATS DIRECTLY IMPACTS LOCAL WILDLIFE POPULATIONS AND EXACERBATES THE VULNERABILITY OF THIS SYSTEM TO SEA-LEVEL RISE AND COASTAL STORM EVENTS. FURTHER, THESE IMPACTS, IF LEFT UNCHECKED, MAY RESULT IN CHANGES IN THE VEGETATIVE COMMUNITY STRUCTURE THAT LEAD TO PERMANENT MARSH LOSS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS A PHASED APPROACH TO HABITAT AND HYDROLOGICAL IMPROVEMENTS TO REDUCE PEAT SATURATION, BUILD SURFACE ELEVATION CAPITAL AND RESTORE A VEGETATED MARSH SURFACE. THESE IMPROVEMENTS WILL BENEFIT THE AT-RISK SALTMARSH SPARROW AND AMERICAN BLACK DUCK. THIS PROJECT IMPROVES HABITAT ON RACHEL CARSON NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, MEETS OBJECTIVES IN THE ATLANTIC COAST JOINT VENTURE SALTMARSH SPARROW CONSERVATION PLAN, AMERICAN BLACK DUCK CONSERVATION PLAN, AND PROMOTES COMMUNITY RESILIENCE.DUCKS UNLIMITED, INC. (DU) UNDERSTANDS THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO RESTORE THE  120-ACRE MARSH AND TO MAXIMIZE MANAGEMENT CAPABILITIES FOR SALTMARSH SPARROW AND PROMOTE COMMUNITY RESILIENCE. IN APRIL 2022, DU COMPLETED A PRELIMINARY SITE INVESTIGATION AND SURVEY. IN CONCERT WITH RCNWR, SEVERAL RESTORATION TECHNIQUES WERE IDENTIFIED TO INCORPORATE INTO RESTORATION DESIGNS. THIS APPROACH WILL REQUIRE A COMBINATION OF TECHNIQUES AT MULTIPLE SPATIAL SCALES AND A PHASED RESTORATION APPROACH. DU WILL ADVANCE RESTORATION DESIGNS, PROVIDE DESIGN DOCUMENTATION FOR PERMIT APPLICATIONS, AND PROVIDE CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT FOR AND OR IMPLEMENT THE CONSTRUCTION OF THE RESTORATION DESIGNS.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) SHIAWASSEE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (SNWR) PROPOSES TO CONTROL 200 ACRES OF INVASIVE PLANTS, INCREASE WATERBIRD UTILIZATION, AND REDUCE NUTRIENT RUN-OFF TO THE SAGINAW BAY AREA OF CONCERN THROUGH AN INNOVATIVE MULTI-YEAR RESTORATION AND RESEARCH PROJECT. THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES GLRI ACTION PLAN III PRIORITIES (FOCUS AREA 2) WHICH CALLS TO DEVELOP INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL TECHNOLOGIES AND REFINE MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES WITH INNOVATIVE EMERGING TECHNOLOGY, IMPLEMENTED AT A LARGE SCALE.WE PROPOSE TO HARVEST INVASIVE HYBRID CATTAIL (TYPHA X GLAUCA) BIOMASS FROM THE 288-ACRE MAANKIKI SOUTH UNIT WITHIN THE SNWR, CONVERT IT TO BIOCHAR ON-SITE, AND RE-APPLY THE BIOCHAR TO A PORTION OF THE UNIT. THE MAANKIKI SOUTH UNIT WAS RESTORED TO WETLAND FROM AGRICULTURAL FIELDS THROUGH A GLRI-FUNDED RESTORATION PROJECT. HOWEVER, DUE TO ITS LEGACY OF AGRICULTURE AND WATERSHED NUTRIENT ENRICHMENT, THE UNIT QUICKLY BECAME DOMINATED BY HYBRID CATTAIL, ALTERING THE WETLAND S ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS AND REDUCING HABITAT QUALITY FOR WATERBIRDS. MANAGING THE CATTAIL WITHIN THE UNIT IS THEREFORE A HIGH PRIORITY FOR SNWR.IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL MANAGE INVASIVE CATTAILS TO THE BENEFIT OF WATERBIRDS ACROSS 200 ACRES OF MAANKIKI SOUTH UNIT, WHILE SIMULTANEOUSLY CONDUCTING A LARGE-SCALE EXPERIMENT TO TEST THE COMBINED EFFICACY OF INVASIVE SPECIES BIOMASS-HARVEST AND BIOCHAR RE-APPLICATION TO ACHIEVE MULTIPLE BENEFITS. WE WILL ESTABLISH A MULTI-YEAR, HIGHLY REPLICATED EXPERIMENT WITH LARGE 2.5-ACRE PLOTS, TWO LEVEL OF BIOCHAR APPLICATION, TWO-LEVELS OF REPEATED HARVEST, AND CONTROLS. WE WILL HARVEST BIOMASS ANNUALLY WITH ALLOW-GROUND-PRESSURE PLANT HARVESTER AND PROCESS IT ON-SITE WITH A MOBILE BIOCHAR PRODUCTION UNIT. THROUGHOUT THE 4-YEAR STUDY, WE WILL MONITOR PLANT RESPONSE, BIRD UTILIZATION, SOIL NUTRIENT LEVELS, PLANT AVAILABLE NUTRIENTS, SOIL CARBON CONTENT, AND NUTRIENT EXPORT FROM THE UNIT.THIS PROJECT BUILDS DIRECTLY ON GLRI SUPPORTED PROJECTS TO RESTORE MAANKIKI SOUTH UNIT AND TO DEVELOP INNOVATIVE INVASIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES. WE ANTICIPATE BROAD ECOLOGICAL BENEFITS INCLUDING THE LONG-TERM REDUCTION OF INVASIVE PLANT DOMINANCE, INCREASED WATERBIRD HABITAT, REDUCED DOWNSTREAM NUTRIENT RUNOFF, AND INCREASED CARBON STORAGE. KNOWLEDGE GAINED WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP MANAGEMENT PROTOCOLS FOR INVASIVE PLANT HARVEST, CONVERSION TO BIOCHAR AND WETLAND RE-APPLICATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A TOOLKIT FOR ESTIMATING VISITATION LEVELS AND TRENDS AT NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES (NWRS). SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, TO A) DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE AND DETAILED OUTLINE FOR 5-10 MODULES FOR A VISITOR ESTIMATION TOOLKIT, SPECIFIC TO USFWS, B) PROVIDE UPDATED DEFINITIONS FOR KEY TERMS USED IN VISITOR ESTIMATION WITH RECOMMENDATIONS FOR USFWS ADOPTION, C) PROVIDE 5-10 HIGH QUALITY, INSTRUCTIONAL TRAINING VIDEOS FOR DIFFERENT VISITOR ESTIMATION FIELD TECHNIQUES FOLLOWING BEST PRACTICES AND INDUSTRY STANDARDS, D) PROVIDE A COMPREHENSIVE CASE STUDY OF A VISITOR ESTIMATION SYSTEM AT A COMPLEX REFUGE TO SHOWCASE TRAINING EXAMPLES AND PROVIDE AN OVERVIEW OF DECISION-MAKING AND TRADEOFFS REGARDING VISITOR ESTIMATION, E) COLLABORATE WITH EXISTING USFWS PROJECT LEADERS, USFWS VISITOR ESTIMATION IMPLEMENTATION TEAM, PHASE 2 PROJECT STATIONS COMPLEXES, THE INTERAGENCY VISITOR USE MANAGEMENT COUNCIL, AND THE NATIONAL CONSERVATION TRAINING CENTER, AND F) ASSIST THE USFWS WITH THE INITIAL DISSEMINATION OF COMPLETED VIDEOS AND COMPREHENSIVE CASE STUDY VIDEOS.     THIS PROJECT, AND SPECIFICALLY VISITOR ESTIMATION, IS IMPORTANT BECAUSE THE NWR SYSTEM HOSTS TENS OF MILLIONS OF VISITORS ANNUALLY ACROSS THE COUNTRY. THESE VISITORS PARTICIPATE IN A VARIETY OF ACTIVITIES RANGING FROM HUNTING AND FISHING, TO HORSEBACK RIDING, TO EDUCATIONAL VISITS FROM LOCAL SCHOOLS. ACCURATELY, EFFICIENTLY, AND CONSISTENTLY ESTIMATING THE NUMBER OF VISITORS TO NWRS IS A CHALLENGE ACROSS THE SERVICE DUE TO THE REMOTE AND POROUS NATURE OF MANY REFUGES, REDUCED STAFFING LEVELS FOR VISITOR SERVICES, AND THE VARIETY OF ACTIVITIES IN WHICH VISITORS ENGAGE. HOWEVER, EVALUATING AND IMPROVING VISITOR ESTIMATION IS CRITICAL TO GROWING VISITATION NUMBERS AND ENHANCING VISITOR EXPERIENCES AT NWRS. VISITATION INFORMATION ALSO HELPS THE SERVICE BETTER DETERMINE BOTH THE BENEFITS AND IMPACTS OF RECREATIONAL USE ON SERVICE LANDS AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND INFORMS LANDSCAPE SCALE CONSERVATION PLANNING EFFORTS BY TRACKING HOW PUBLIC LAND USAGE IS CHANGING IN RESPONSE TO SOCIO-ECONOMIC AND DEMOGRAPHIC CHANGES.    PREVIOUS STUDIES HAVE DEMONSTRATED THAT STAFF TRAINING AND EMPLOYEE EDUCATION REGARDING VISITOR ESTIMATION IS LACKING WITHIN THE SERVICE LEADING FIELD STAFF TO FEEL FRUSTRATED AND CHALLENGED WITH ACQUIRING ACCURATE AND EFFICIENT VISITOR ESTIMATES (DAGAN ET AL., 2021). THIS STUDY ADDRESSES THE TRAINING GAP BY PROVIDING RESOURCES (E.G., VIDEOS, CASE STUDIES, TOOLKIT OUTLINE) THAT CAN BE USED TO HELP FIELD STAFF MORE EFFICIENTLY AND ACCURATELY ESTIMATE VISITOR NUMBERS TO NWRS. ULTIMATELY, THIS PROJECT IS NECESSARY TO ENSURE THAT VISITOR USE MANAGEMENT, INFRASTRUCTURE, AND MANAGEMENT DECISIONS AT NWRS ARE LEGALLY DEFENSIBLE, SENSITIVE TO CONSTITUENT NEEDS, AND INCORPORATE FUTURE VISITOR USE PROJECTIONS WHILE PRESERVING DESIRABLE CONDITIONS AND HABITAT.

THIS PROGRAM AIMS TO OVERCOME THE BARRIERS PEOPLE FROM UNDER-RESOURCED COMMUNITIES IN SOUTHEAST SAN DIEGO COUNTY FACE, TO MEANINGFULLY CONNECT WITH NATURE, AND TO ENGAGE PARTICIPANTS AS PARTNERS IN CONSERVATION. THIS WORK DIRECTLY SUPPORTS EARTH DISCOVERY INSTITUTE S MISSION,  TO INSPIRE STEWARDSHIP OF SAN DIEGO S NATIVE BIODIVERSITY THROUGH ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND CONSERVATION.  EARTH DISCOVERY INSTITUTE WORKS EXCLUSIVELY WITH TITLE 1 SCHOOLS AND HAS BROUGHT MORE THAN 30,000 CHILDREN TO ENGAGE IN SCIENCE-BASED, HANDS-ON ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION ON CONSERVED LAND IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY. OUR GOAL IS TO ENSURE AS MANY KIDS AS POSSIBLE FROM THESE COMMUNITIES ENJOY THE OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT AND PERSONALLY EXPERIENCE OUR WILD LANDSCAPES.

UNDER THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT, THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION (NFWF) AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) WILL PARTNER TO ADVANCE CONSERVATION ACTIONS ON THE SOUTH FARALLON ISLANDS. THESE ISLANDS SERVE AS CRITICAL HABITAT FOR THE ASHY STORM-PETREL (ASSP). NFWF HAS SUPPORTED ASSP CONSERVATION PROJECTS OVER THE PAST DECADE THROUGH ITS SEABIRD PROGAM. THE PROPOSED PARTNERSHIP WILL BRING TOGETHER FUNDING FROM THE SERVICE AND THE PRIVATE SECTOR THROUGH NFWF S SEABIRD PROGRAM TO ELIMINATE THREATS FROM INVASIVE SPECIES ON THE SOUTH FARALLON ISLANDS.

BACKCOUNTRY HUNTERS   ANGLERS (BHA) AND THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE WILL WORK TOGETHER ON A NATIONAL LEVEL TO ADVANCE SHARED STEWARDSHIP, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PRIORITIES ON U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE LANDS.  BHA STAFF WILL COORDINATE REGULARLY WITH BOTH USFWS HQ AND FIELD STAFF TO IDENTIFY, PLAN AND IMPLEMENT PROJECTS WHICH ADVANCE THE STEWARDSHIP OF OUR PUBLIC LANDS AND OR OUR HUNTING AND FISHING HERITAGE.  BHA WILL MOBILIZE IT S RICH VOLUNTEER BASE TO COMPLETE THESE PROJECT PRIORITIES.

THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF NATIONAL TRAILS DAY AND VOLUNTEER VACATIONS ACTIVITIES ACROSS THE NATION ON FWS FIELD STATIONS AMERICAN HIKING SOCIETY (AHS) AND UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH FWS FIELD STATION MANAGERS, TO ORGANIZE NATIONAL TRAILS DAY (NTD) EVENTS AND VOLUNTEER VACATIONS THAT WILL ADDRESS TRAIL MAINTENANCE NEEDS AT FWS FIELD STATIONS. THIS VOLUNTEER MAINTENANCE WILL RESULT IN TRAILS THAT WILL BE SAFE FOR THE PUBLIC TO USE AND BE SUSTAINABLY BUILT, WHICH WILL SIGNIFICANTLY DECREASE THE AMOUNT OF TRAIL UPKEEP AND MAINTENANCE EXPENSE IN THE FUTURE. ADDITIONALLY, NTD WILL INVITE AMERICANS OF ALL WALKS OF LIFE TO DISCOVER OUTDOOR RECREATION AND VOLUNTEER OPPORTUNITIES AT FWS SITES, TO ENJOY OUR PUBLIC LANDS WHILE LEADING TO INCREASED SUPPORT FOR THESE LANDS.

THE LIVING COAST CENTER PROVIDES HANDS-ON ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES AT THE SWEETWATER MARSH UNIT OF THE SAN DIEGO BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. THE LIVING COAST INSPIRES THE COMMUNITY TO CONNECT WITH AND CARE FOR OUR COASTAL ENVIRONMENT. OUR PROGRAMS SERVE K-12 STUDENTS, AND TEACHERS IN UNDERSERVED AND TITLE 1 SCHOOLS, AND FAMILIES THROUGHOUT THE SAN DIEGO REGION REPRESENTING DIVERSE ETHNIC, CULTURAL, AND ECONOMIC BACKGROUNDS.TODAY, MORE THAN 80 PERCENT OF AMERICAN FAMILIES LIVE IN URBAN AREAS, AND MANY LACK EASY ACCESS TO SAFE OUTDOOR SPACES, ACCORDING TO THE U.S. DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR. AT THE SAME TIME, KIDS ARE SPENDING MORE HOURS THAN EVER BEFORE IN FRONT OF SCREENS INSTEAD OF OUTSIDE. PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS AND FAMILIES TO SPEND TIME OUTDOORS ALLOWS THEM TO EXPERIENCE THE NATURAL WORLD AROUND THEM AND INSPIRES POSITIVE ATTITUDES TOWARDS THE ENVIRONMENT.WITH SUPPORT FROM U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND THE SOCAL URBAN WILDLIFE REFUGE PROJECT, THE LIVING COAST WILL CONNECT PEOPLE WITH NATURE THROUGH A VARIETY OF PROGRAMS INCLUDING REFUGE-BASED FIELD TRIPS AND FAMILY PROGRAMS. AS A COMMUNITY ASSET, WE WILL PROVIDE EQUITABLE ACCESS TO INDIVIDUALS AND SCHOOLS THAT WOULD NOT OTHERWISE HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO EXPERIENCE THE SWEETWATER MARSH AND LIVING COAST DISCOVERY CENTER.OVER 60  OF CHULA VISTA RESIDENTS IDENTIFY AS HISPANIC LATINO, AND 47  SPEAK SPANISH. PEOPLE OF COLOR AND ENGLISH LANGUAGE LEARNERS HAVE BEEN EXCLUDED FROM SCIENCE RESEARCH AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION, AND RESEARCH SHOWS THAT A SENSE OF BELONGING IN NATURE IS A FOUNDATIONAL ELEMENT TO DEVELOPING A PRO-ENVIRONMENTAL IDENTITY. A 2015 STUDY BY LATINO DECISIONS, A POLLING FIRM FOCUSING ON HISPANICS IN AMERICA, FOUND THAT OVER 80  OF HISPANICS IN THE COUNTRY ARE CONCERNED WITH THE NEGATIVE IMPACT HUMANS HAVE ON THE ENVIRONMENT, HOWEVER, AT LEAST 77  OF THEM SAID THEY DON T FEEL ENCOURAGED BY LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS TO GET INVOLVED. SUPPORTING BILINGUAL PROFESSIONALS IN THE ENVIRONMENTAL WORKFORCE AND PROVIDING THEM THE LEADERSHIP OPPORTUNITIES TO CONNECT WITH THEIR OWN COMMUNITY WILL STRENGTHEN OUR MISSION AND THE STEM FIELD IN GENERAL.

THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) HAS IDENTIFIED THE ALEUTIAN TERN AS A SEABIRD OF HIGH CONSERVATION CONCERN. ALEUTIAN TERN BREEDING SITES ARE RESTRICTED TO ALASKA AND THE RUSSIAN FAR EAST. WHILE POPULATION TREND INFORMATION FOR RUSSIAN POPULATIONS IS SPARSE, POPULATIONS AT KNOWN BREEDING SITES IN ALASKA HAVE DECLINED DRAMATICALLY IN RECENT DECADES. A RECENT STUDY ESTIMATED THE POPULATION AT KNOWN BREEDING COLONIES HAS DECLINED BY 8.1  ANNUALLY SINCE 1960, OR 92.9  OVER THREE GENERATIONS. GIVEN THE LACK OF A FORMAL MONITORING EFFORT ACROSS THE RANGE, UNCERTAINTIES RELATED TO CENSUS METHODS, AND AN INABILITY TO ASSESS IF BIRDS HAVE DISPERSED FROM DECLINING COLONIES TO AS-OF-YET UNKNOWN COLONIES, ALEUTIAN TERN HAS BEEN INCLUDED ON SEVERAL SPECIES WATCH LISTS. THE USFWS HAS GREAT INTEREST IN COLLECTING INFORMATION THAT WOULD PROVIDE A STATUS UPDATE FOR THE SPECIES. THROUGH THE ALEUTIAN TERN TECHNICAL COMMITTEE WORKING GROUP, THE USFWS IS UNDERTAKING A PROJECT TO DETERMINE DISTRIBUTION AND ABUNDANCE OF ALEUTIAN TERNS AT A STATEWIDE SCALE. FUNDS ARE AVAILABLE TO SUPPORT A THREE-YEAR STUDY (2023-2025) THAT WILL INVOLVE AERIAL SURVEYS TO IDENTIFY CURRENT BREEDING COLONY LOCATIONS, AND ON-THE-GROUND ACCESS TO COLONIES TO ESTIMATE TERN ABUNDANCE. GIVEN THE STUDY DESIGN, THE COMPLICATED LOGISTICS, AND THE VAST GEOGRAPHY, THE USFWS HAS IDENTIFIED THE NEED FOR A DEDICATED COORDINATOR TO SUPPORT DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STATEWIDE ALEUTIAN TERN CENSUS. THE PRINCE WILLIAM SOUND SCIENCE CENTER (PWSSC) THROUGH THEIR EXISTING COOPERATIVE ECOSYSTEM STUDIES UNIT AGREEMENT AND STAFF EXPERTISE IS UNIQUELY QUALIFIED TO FILL THE COORDINATOR ROLE IN YEAR 1. ANNE SCHAEFER, WHO WILL SERVE AS THE COORDINATOR, WILL COORDINATE PLANNING AND LEAD IMPLEMENTATION OF THE 2023 AERIAL AND GROUND-BASED TERN SURVEYS IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA FROM CORDOVA TO GUSTAVUS. PLANNING AND LOGISTICS WILL BEGIN IN JANUARY 2023, AND INCLUDE COORDINATING AND LEADING MEETINGS WITH THE WORKING GROUP, HIRING AND TRAINING FIELD CREW, ARRANGING TRAVEL AND LODGING FOR THE FIELD CREW, PROCURING SURVEY GEAR, COORDINATING WITH THE PILOT, SECURING ADDITIONAL PILOTS AND AIRCRAFT AS NEEDED, OBTAINING NECESSARY PERMITS FOR LAND ACCESS, AND DEVELOPING A BUDGET. FIELD ACTIVITIES WILL BE CONDUCTED MAY-JUNE, 2023. THE COORDINATOR WILL IMPLEMENT THE SURVEY PLAN DEVELOPED BY THE WORKING GROUP, WHICH WILL INCLUDE COMMUNICATING DAILY WITH THE PILOT(S), FIELD CREWS, AND THE BIOMETRICIAN, OVERSEEING DATA COLLECTION IN THE FIELD, AND CONDUCTING FIELD WORK AS NEEDED. THE COORDINATOR WILL WORK WITH THE BIOMETRICIAN TO COLLATE SURVEY RESULTS, QA QC DATA, AND ENTER DATA INTO THE DATABASE, AND WILL LEAD THE EFFORT TO DRAFT AN ANNUAL REPORT THAT SUMMARIZES THE STUDY OBJECTIVES, METHODS, RESULTS, AND KEY FINDINGS. THE COORDINATOR WILL ALSO WORK TO MEET REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR ACCESS AND OTHER RELEVANT PERMITS (SEPTEMBER THROUGH FEBRUARY).THE COORDINATOR S SUCCESS WITH PLANNING LOGISTICS, IMPLEMENTING THE STUDY DESIGN, SUPERVISING AND LEADING DATA COLLECTION, COMMUNICATING CLOSELY WITH THE BIOMETRICIAN AND THE PLANNING TEAM, AND MEETING REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR COMPLIANCE WILL BE CRITICAL TO THE PROGRAM S OVERALL OBJECTIVE OF ESTIMATING BREEDING ALEUTIAN TERN ABUNDANCE IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA.THE DRAFT REPORT SUMMARIZING THE 2023 SURVEY EFFORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED ELECTRONICALLY TO THE WORKING GROUP BY SEPTEMBER 15, 2023. THE COORDINATOR WILL WORK TO INCORPORATE COMMENTS INTO SUBSEQUENT VERSIONS OF THE REPORT THROUGH FEBRUARY. THE FINALIZED REPORT WILL BE DISBURSED AMONG THE WORKING GROUP AS WELL AS TO INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS (E.G., ICY BAY LODGE, NATIONAL PARK WILDERNESS PARTNERS).

DALE BUMPERS WHITE RIVER (DBWR) NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (NWR), CONTAINING OVER 160,000 ACRES OFLAND, THE REFUGE PROTECTS ONE OF THE LARGEST REMAINING BOTTOMLAND HARDWOOD FOREST IN THE MISSISSIPPIALLUVIAL VALLEY (MAV). ESTABLISHED IN 1940, THE REFUGE IS MANAGED AS AN IMPORTANT RESTING AND FEEDINGAREA FOR WINTERING WATERFOWL, AS WELL AS PROVIDING HABITAT FOR NUMEROUS RESIDENT WILDLIFE SPECIES ANDOTHER MIGRATORY BIRDS.THERE ARE TWO AREAS ON DBWR NWR THAT ARE IN NEED OF REPAIR, SPECIFICALLY THE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE ONWOLF BAYOU AS WELL AS THE LEVEE B ROAD WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE. THE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE AT WOLFBAYOU PROVIDES GREEN TREE HABITAT MANAGEMENT ALONG WOLF BAYOU AND ALLOWS WATER PASSAGE UNDER JACKSBAY LEVEE ROAD. THE EXISTING STEEL SHEET PILE AND CONCRETE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE IS BADLY DAMAGED ANDSPALLED. THE EXISTING STOPLOGS AND CHANNELS DO NOT PROPERLY FUNCTION. THE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE NEEDSTO BE REPLACED.FOR THE LEVEE B ROAD WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE, THE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE PROVIDES GREEN TREE HABITATMANAGEMENT ALONG HONEY LOCUST BAYOU AND ALLOWS WATER PASSAGE UNDER LEVEE B ROAD. THE EXISTINGCONCRETE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE IS BADLY SPALLED AND CRACKED AND THE EXISTING GATES AND CONTROLLERS ARESEVERELY RUSTED AND DO NOT FUNCTION. THE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE NEEDS TO BE REPLACED.THE GREAT AMERICAN OUTDOORS ACT FUNDED PROJECT TO REPLACE THE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES AT WOLF BAYOUAND HONEY LOCUST GTR WILL GREATLY BENEFIT THE PUBLIC BECAUSE THESE ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR HOLDING WATER ONA POPULAR DUCK HUNTING AREA OF DALE BUMPERS WRNWR. DUCK HUNTING IS OPEN IN THIS AREA ON EVERYTUESDAY, THURSDAY, SATURDAY AND SUNDAY FROM SUNRISE UNTIL NOON DURING THE STATEWIDE DUCK SEASON.THERE ARE ONLY TWO AREAS OPEN TO DUCK HUNTING ON THE 100,000 ACRE SOUTH UNIT OF THE REFUGE, WITH THISBEING ONE OF THEM. ACCESS TO THIS AREA IS BY BOAT, FOOT OR ATV ON DESIGNATED ATV TRAILS. THESE WATERCONTROL STRUCTURES ARE USED TO MANAGE THE WATER LEVEL ON A 2,500 ACRE GREENTREE RESERVOIR THAT HAS BEENOPEN TO DUCK HUNTING SINCE 1979. NOT ONLY ARE THESE STRUCTURES CRITICAL FOR HOLDING WATER ONTO THEBOTTOMLAND FOREST TO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR WINTERING WATERFOWL AND DUCK HUNTING OPPORTUNITY BUT THEY ARECRITICAL FOR GETTING WATER OFF OF THE FORESTED HABITAT DURING THE SPRING AND SUMMER. WITHOUT THE ABILITY TOREMOVE WATER FROM THE FORESTED HABITAT DURING THE GROWING SEASON, THE TREES WILL DIE FROM WATER STRESSAND HABITAT CONVERSION WILL OCCUR RESULTING IN LESS PUBLIC HUNTING, ATV, AND FOOT ACCESS OPPORTUNITIES.BOTH OF THESE STRUCTURES ARE CURRENTLY IN A FAILED CONDITION AND ARE NOT PROVIDING THE WATER CONTROL TOTHEIR DESIGNED INTENDED CAPACITY. UPON THE COMPLETION OF THESE NEW WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES, OURABILITY TO DE-WATER THESE IMPOUNDMENTS WILL BE GREATLY IMPROVED ALLOWING PUBLIC ACCESS DURING THE DRYSEASON AND PUBLIC HUNTING OPPORTUNITIES DURING THE WINTER MONTHS.

IN APRIL OF 2021 A PYTHON SIGHTING WAS REPORTED A FEW MILES NORTHEAST OF THE OKEFENOKEE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (REFUGE). THE SIGHTING OCCURRED IN THE SAME AREA WHERE A PYTHON HAD BEEN KILLED SEVERAL YEARS BEFORE. THERE IS A CONFIRMED ACTIVE RETAIL BREEDER OF PYTHONS IN FOLKSTON, GA, AND THEIR OPERATIONS COULD BE A SOURCE FOR AN INCIPIENT POPULATION. IF PYTHONS BECOME ESTABLISHED IN THE SWAMP, THEY WILL HAVE DEVASTATING, ECOSYSTEM-WIDE IMPLICATIONS AS THEY HAVE HAD IN THE EVERGLADES. IT IS VITAL FOR THE ENTIRE OKEFENOKEE SWAMP ECOSYSTEM THAT ANY INSIPIENT POPULATIONS OF INVADERS, AND ESPECIALLY PYTHONS, ARE DISCOVERED EARLY SO THAT IF THEY ARE PRESENT, THERE IS AN OPPORTUNITY TO ERADICATE THEM BEFORE THEY BECOME BROADLY ESTABLISHED. GIVEN THIS NEED, THE REFUGE PROPOSES TO USE THE CUTTING-EDGE TECHNOLOGY OF ENVIRONMENTAL (E)DNA TO SURVEY AROUND THE REFUGE FOR THE PRESENCE OF PYTHONS. ENVIRONMENTAL DNA METHODS ENABLE RESEARCHERS TO CAPTURE AND ASSAY MINISCULE AMOUNTS OF DNA THAT HAVE BEEN SHED INTO THE ENVIRONMENT BY ORGANISMS LIVING IN OR INTERACTING WITH THE AIR, WATER, OR SOIL. PRESENCE OF PYTHON DNA WOULD ALERT THE REFUGE AT AREAS WHERE THE PYTHONS COULD BE PRESENT SO ADDITIONAL INVENTORY AND MONITORING COULD BE PLANNED, ALONG WITH ERADICATION MEASURES IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE STATE DIVISION OF NATURAL RESOURCES AND LOCAL LANDOWNERS.

THE PRIBILOF SEABIRD YOUTH NETWORK (SYN) IS A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE ALASKA MARITIME NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, THE PRIBILOF SCHOOL DISTRICT, ST. GEORGE ISLAND TRADITIONAL COUNCIL, ALEUT COMMUNITY OF ST. PAUL AND THE WIDER SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY. THIS UNIQUE PARTNERSHIP PROVIDES YOUTH (K-12 STUDENTS ON BOTH PRIBILOF ISLANDS) AN INCREDIBLE CHANCE TO LEARN ABOUT SEABIRDS, AND CONTRIBUTE TO VALUABLE LONG-TERM DATA SETS ON LOCAL SEABIRD POPULATIONS. THE SYN WAS DESIGNED TO BUILD LOCAL CAPACITY FOR THE COLLECTION OF LONG-TERM MONITORING DATA ON THE PRIBILOF ISLANDS. SYN CAMP PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL YOUTH TO LEARN ABOUT SEABIRDS, PROMOTE SCIENCE TO NATIVE YOUTH, AND PROVIDE NEW EXPERIENCES FOR STUDENTS AND ENCOURAGE SELF-CONFIDENCE.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD WILL ALLOW FRIENDS OF NEVADA WILDERNESS TO CONTINUE A MULTI-YEAR HABITAT RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION PROJECT ON LANDS WITHIN THE SHELDON NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, INCLUDING PROPOSED WILDERNESS AREAS. USING A THREE OR FOUR PERSON CREW, FNW WILL CONTINUE PRIORITY WORK AS DETERMINED BY THE REFUGE STAFF SUCH AS: LOCATION AND REMOVAL OF ANY REMAINING INTERIOR FENCING AND NON-FUNCTIONING WATER DEVELOPMENTS  SPRING REHABILITATION  INVENTORY AND TREATMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES  POSTING OF PROPOSED WILDERNESS BOUNDARY SIGNS  REMOVAL OF CLOSED ROAD ROUTE SEGMENTS IN PROPOSED WILDERNESS  PROTECTING RIPARIAN HABITATS BY CONSTRUCTING EXCLOSURE FENCES  AND MONITORING EXTERIOR BOUNDARY FENCING TO PREVENT FERAL HORSES FROM ENTERING THE REFUGE.

IN COLLABORATION WITH THE U.S. FISH AND  WILDLIFE SERVICE  THE RECIPIENT SHALL BRING TOGETHER UP TO 175 FRIENDS FROM OFFICIAL USFWS E FRIENDS ORGANIZATIONS AND UP TO 100 USFWS EMPLOYEES TO NETWORK, RECEIVE TRAINING IN BEST PRACTICES, STRENGTHEN PARTNERSHIPS AT THE LOCAL, REGIONAL AND NATIONAL LEVEL, AND DELIVER IMPORTANT INFORMATION REGARDING ADHERING TO AGENCY POLICY AND ETHICS GUIDELINES. PROPOSED GOALS  OUR GOAL, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, IS TO CREATE A ROBUST AND EFFECTIVE FRIENDS WORKSHOP. WE ENVISION THAT THE WORKSHOP WILL BE AN OPPORTUNITY WHERE FRIENDS GROUPS AND SERVICE EMPLOYEES ALIKE CAN SHARE INFORMATION. IT IS OUR INTENT THAT FRIENDS GROUPS AND SERVICE EMPLOYEES WILL BE ATTRACTED TO THIS NATIONAL WORKSHOP BECAUSE OF IMMERSIVE ENGAGEMENT AND LEARNING THROUGH WORKSHOP SESSIONS, PLENARIES AND NETWORKING OPPORTUNITIES.

THE NORTH AMERICAN CARIBOU WORKSHOP AND  ARCTIC UNGULATE CONFERENCE WILL BRING PEOPLE TOGETHER IN ANCHORAGE, ALASKA TO SHARE INFORMATION, KNOWLEDGE, AND PERSPECTIVES ON STEWARDSHIP OF ARCTIC UNGULATES (CARIBOU, REINDEER, MUSKOXEN, DALL SHEEP, AND MOOSE). THE CONFERENCE THEME IS CROSSING BOUNDARIES. ARCTIC UNGULATES CROSS LANDSCAPE AND MANAGEMENT BOUNDARIES, AND THE KNOWLEDGE AND VALUE OF THESE SPECIES CROSS THE BOUNDARIES OF WESTERN SCIENCE AND INDIGENOUS KNOWLEDGE. THE CONFERENCE SEEKS TO WEAVE THESE VARIOUS WAYS OF KNOWING TO IDENTIFY CREATIVE OPPORTUNITIES TO MANAGE AND SUSTAIN ARCTIC UNGULATE POPULATIONS IN A CHANGING WORLD.WE WILL BRING TOGETHER HUNDREDS OF PARTICIPANTS FROM AROUND THE ARCTIC, REPRESENTING INDIGENOUS AND NON INDIGENOUS PERSPECTIVES ON ARCTIC UNGULATES. THIS WEEK LONG CONFERENCE (8 12 MAY 2023) WILL BE AN OPPORTUNITY FOR GATHERING, BUILDING RELATIONSHIPS, SHARING IDEAS, AND DEVELOPING NEW EFFORTS TO SUSTAIN ARCTIC UNGULATE POPULATIONS AND THE PEOPLE WHO RELY UPON THEM IN A CHANGING WORLD. CONFERENCE ACTIVITIES WILL BUILD CONNECTIONS BETWEEN PARTICIPANTS AND FACILITATE SHARING OF DIVERSE KNOWLEDGE TYPES. WE ARE STRIVING TO CHANGE THE WAY SCIENTIFIC CONFERENCES ARE TYPICALLY DONE TO BE MORE INCLUSIVE OF DIFFERENT PERSPECTIVES, WAYS OF KNOWING AND MEANS OF COMMUNICATION REGARDING ARCTIC UNGULATES. IN PART, THIS MEANS BRINGING IN ELDERS AND OTHER INDIGENOUS WISDOM KEEPERS FROM ALASKA AND CANADA TO SHARE THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERIENCE PASSED DOWN THROUGH GENERATIONS LIVING ON THE LAND WITH UNGULATES. WE ALSO SEEK TO GO BEYOND CLASSICAL WESTERN SCIENTIFIC TALKS AND POSTERS TO INCLUDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR FISHBOWL DISCUSSIONS AND PANELS FEATURING EXPERTS FROM INDIGENOUS AND WESTERN SCIENTIFIC BACKGROUNDS, SHOWCASING OF ARTWORK AND HANDICRAFTS AT OUR EVENING POSTER SOCIAL, HOLDING A MINI FILM FESTIVAL THAT INCLUDES INDIGENOUS LED CONTENT, AND HOSTING A STORYTELLING EVENT WHERE INDIGENOUS AND WESTERN SCIENTIFIC PARTICIPANTS CAN BE UNITED THROUGH THE SHARED MEDIUM OF STORIES RELATED TO ARCTIC UNGULATES. WE WILL PROMOTE RELATIONSHIP BUILDING BETWEEN PEOPLE IN SUPPORT OF MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION OF ARCTIC UNGULATES IN THE UNITED STATES AND WORLDWIDE.

ACCORDING TO ATLANTIC COAST LAND MANAGERS, HUMAN DISTURBANCE IS THE GREATEST THREAT FACING SHOREBIRDS, ABOVE THE PRESSURES OF HABITAT LOSS AND CLIMATE CHANGE. WHEN THE NORMAL BEHAVIORS AND ACTIVITIES OF A BIRD ARE ALTERED BY SOMETHING, SUCH AS PEOPLE OR DOGS, THIS IS REFERRED TO AS DISTURBANCE. THE THREAT OF DISTURBANCE IS ESCALATING AS COASTAL AREAS ARE BECOMING MORE POPULATED AND DEVELOPED, LEAVING SHOREBIRDS TO COMPETE FOR THEIR HABITAT WITH RECREATIONISTS, TOURISTS, AND LOCALS THROUGH INCREASED INTERACTIONS. CONTINUOUS INTERACTIONS WITH BEACHGOERS CAN HAVE SIGNIFICANT NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON SHOREBIRDS AND MAKES THEM MORE SUSCEPTIBLE TO DISTURBANCE  THEREFORE, IT IS ESSENTIAL TO IMPROVE SHOREBIRD MANAGEMENT IN WAYS THAT PRIORITIZE SOCIAL SCIENCE TO BETTER UNDERSTAND HOW TO ADDRESS THE CHALLENGE AND INVOLVE BEACHGOERS IN CONSERVATION ACTIONS. TO ADDRESS DISTURBANCE ISSUES IN THE NORTHEAST, THE DAYER HUMAN DIMENSIONS LAB AT VIRGINIA TECH WILL WORK WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO APPLY AND BUILD ON THE INSIGHTS AND TOOLS FROM THE GUIDE TO APPLYING SCIENCE AND MANAGEMENT INSIGHTS AND HUMAN BEHAVIOR CHANGE STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS BEACH WALKING AND DOG DISTURBANCE ALONG THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY  DEVELOPED BY VIRGINIA TECH AND PARTNERS. THIS COLLABORATIVE WORK WILL INVOLVE PILOTING AT LEAST TWO COMMUNITY BASED SOCIAL MARKETING CAMPAIGNS IN THE NORTHEAST NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES  SUPPORTING NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE STAFF THROUGH ONLINE TRAININGS AND A VIRTUAL COMMUNITY OR PRACTICE  PROVIDING AN IN PERSON CONSULTATION TO DIAGNOSE DISTURBANCE AND CONFLICT PROBLEMS AND STRATEGIZE SOCIAL SCIENCE APPROACHES TO ALLEVIATING THESE ISSUES  ASSESSING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE FUNDED PROJECTS THROUGH THE CREATION OF A LOGIC MODEL AND PROGRAMMATIC EVALUATION METRICS OF PROJECT SUCCESS  AND REVIEWING AND ADVISING COMMUNICATIONS CONTENT FOR THE REGION 5 SHOREBIRD STEWARD TRAINING PROGRAM. THIS WORK WILL BE ESSENTIAL TO DEVELOPING SCALABLE CONSERVATION STRATEGIES THAT CAN BE APPLIED AT NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES ALONG THE ATLANTIC FLYWAY TO POSITIVELY CHANGE HUMAN BEHAVIOR, MINIMIZE HUMAN DISTURBANCE TO SHOREBIRDS, AND IMPROVE SHOREBIRD SURVIVAL AND REPRODUCTIVE SUCCESS.

IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE SIKES ACT AND IMPROVEMENT AMENDMENTS, FAIRCHILD AIR FORCE BASE (AFB) IN SPOKANE COUNTY, WA IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE MANAGEMENT OF THE NATURAL RESOURCES ON THE BASE, AS OUTLINED IN THEIR INTEGRATED NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PLAN. THROUGH PARTNERSHIP WITH THE AIR FORCE, WE, THE USFWS, PROVIDE COOPERATIVE LEADERSHIP AND SUPPORT FOR THE CONSERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES ON THESE MILITARY INSTALLATIONS. THE EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION OF THE VARIOUS NATURAL COMMUNITIES ON FAIRCHILD AFB REQUIRES PERIODIC INVENTORIES AND SURVEYS TO IDENTIFY THE SPECIES OCCUPYING THE BASE AND THE PRESENCE OF ANY SPECIES OF CONCERN.MOST OF THE SHRUB STEPPE AND BISCUIT SCABLANDS IN EASTERN WASHINGTON HAVE BEEN LOST TO WILDFIRES, CONVERSION TO AGRICULTURE, AND DEVELOPMENT, WHILE MUCH OF THE REMAINING HABITATS ARE FRAGMENTED AND DEGRADED. THIS HAS LED TO CONSERVATION CONCERN FOR FAUNA IN CENTRAL AND EASTERN WASHINGTON (E.G., BEALL AND ZEOLI, 2008). THE SOUTHERN PORTION OF FAIRCHILD AFB HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A UNIQUE EXAMPLE AMONG THE REMNANTS IN THE REGION, AS IT IS LARGELY INTACT AND PROTECTED FROM MOST ANTHROPOGENIC DISTURBANCES.

COASTAL WETLANDS ARE HIGHLY ALTERED AND VULNERABLE ECOSYSTEMS DUE TO WIDESPREAD AND FREQUENT LAND-USE CHANGE COUPLED WITH SEA-LEVEL RISE (SLR), LEADING TO DISRUPTED HYDROLOGICAL AND ECOLOGICAL FUNCTIONS, EXTENSIVE WETLAND MIGRATION AND LOSS, AND, ULTIMATELY, REDUCED COASTAL LANDSCAPE RESILIENCY. KNOWING WHERE AND WHEN CHANGES HAVE OCCURRED AND THE DRIVERS OF THOSE CHANGES, IS CRITICAL FOR PREDICTING AND MANAGING THE FUTURE OF COASTAL WETLANDS. YET, NATIONAL-SCALE ANALYSES OF CHANGE IN COASTAL ENVIRONMENTS ARE EXTREMELY DIFFICULT TO UNDERTAKE DUE TO THE INHERENTLY DYNAMIC NATURE OF COASTAL SYSTEMS AND THE LOGISTICAL CONSTRAINTS OF IN-SITU DATA COLLECTION. THEREFORE, IN THIS PROPOSAL WE INTEGRATE NOVEL REMOTE SENSING TIME SERIES MODELING TO CHARACTERIZE THE CHANGES AND IDENTIFY DRIVERS OF COASTAL WETLAND CHANGE FOR THE CONTERMINOUS UNITED STATES (CONUS).THE CONUS COASTAL LANDSCAPE HAS A DIVERSE MIXTURE OF LAND USES, RANGING FROM MAJOR CITIES AND SUBURBIA TO BOTH INTENSIVE AGRICULTURAL AND RELATIVELY UNDISTURBED NATURAL LANDSCAPES, AS WELL AS VARIED TYPES OF COASTLINES (E.G., COASTAL PLAINS, MAJOR ESTUARIES, BARRIER BEACHES, AND ROCKY SHORELINES). COLLECTIVELY, THESE INTERACTING CLIMATE, HUMAN, AND ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSORS DIRECTLY AND INDIRECTLY INFLUENCE COASTAL ECOSYSTEMS. COASTAL WETLANDS IN PARTICULAR EXPERIENCE WIDESPREAD LAND COVER TYPE TRANSITIONS (WETLAND MIGRATION TO UPLAND AREAS AND LOSS, OR CONVERSION, TO NON-WETLAND LAND COVERS LIKE OPEN WATER AND TIDAL FLATS) AS WELL AS LAND COVER CONDITION CHANGE (CHANGE IN WETLAND ECOLOGICAL AND HYDROLOGIC FUNCTION THAT MAY OR MAY NOT LEAD TO A COVER TYPE TRANSITION). WETLAND CONDITION CHANGES MAY SERVE AS IMPORTANT INDICATORS OF TIPPING POINTS THAT LEAD TO IRREVERSIBLE LAND COVER TYPE TRANSITIONS. GIVEN THE NATURE AND CONSEQUENCES OF WETLAND CHANGE FOR COASTAL HEALTH, IT IS IMPERATIVE TO MAP AND BETTER UNDERSTAND THE DRIVERS OF CHANGE, BOTH BETWEEN AND WITHIN COVER TYPES. OUR GOAL IS TO ANALYZE THESE CHANGES AND ASSOCIATED DRIVERS TO PROVIDE GUIDANCE TO MANAGERS IN CONUS AND ENHANCE COASTAL WETLAND PROTECTION.TO ACCOMPLISH OUR GOALS, WE WILL IMPROVE RECENTLY DEVELOPED APPROACHES THAT USE TIME SERIES ANALYSIS TO EXAMINE COASTAL WETLAND CHANGE FROM LANDSAT OBSERVATIONS FROM THE LAST 40 YEARS. LINKING THESE METHODS AND DATA WILL ALLOW US TO DISENTANGLE HOW MAJOR HUMAN AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROCESSES ALTER COASTAL WETLAND ECOSYSTEMS ACROSS THE CONUS. ALL AVAILABLE LANDSAT OBSERVATIONS FROM 1982 TO 2022 WILL BE USED TO BUILD A HARMONIC TIME SERIES MODEL TO TRACK THE 40-YEAR TEMPORAL TRAJECTORY OF EACH PIXEL AT A SPATIAL RESOLUTION OF 30 M  30 M. THE TIME SERIES-BASED MODEL WILL OUTPUT CHANGES (I.E., COVER CHANGE OR CONDITION CHANGE), COVERS (I.E., MANGROVE, TIDAL MARSH AND TIDAL FLATS) AND A SET OF POTENTIAL DRIVERS (E.G., HUMAN DEVELOPMENT, ALTERED HYDROLOGY, ACCELERATED SLR, AND EXTREME STORM SURGE) TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE UNDERLYING MECHANISMS THAT CAUSE CHANGE. THE DEVELOPED METHOD IS HIGHLY TRANSFERABLE TO OTHER COASTAL REGIONS.

THE LIVING COAST DISCOVERY CENTER PROVIDES HANDS-ON ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES AT THE SWEETWATER MARSH UNIT OF THE SAN DIEGO BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. THE LIVING COAST INSPIRES THE COMMUNITY TO CONNECT WITH AND CARE FOR OUR COASTAL ENVIRONMENT. WORKING WITH U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) AND THE SOCAL URBAN WILDLIFE REFUGE PROJECT, THE LIVING COAST WILL CONNECT PEOPLE FROM URBAN AREAS WITH NATURE THROUGH TWO PROGRAMS: URBAN REFUGE NATURE EXPLORERS AND SWEETWATER SAFARI. AS A COMMUNITY ASSET, WE WILL PROVIDE EQUITABLE ACCESS TO INDIVIDUALS AND SCHOOLS THAT WOULD NOT OTHERWISE HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO EXPERIENCE THE SWEETWATER MARSH AND LIVING COAST DISCOVERY CENTER.IN URBAN REFUGE NATURE EXPLORERS, STUDENTS LEARN HOW REFUGES CAME ABOUT AND THEIR PURPOSE, UNDERSTAND WHO LIVES ON REFUGES, AND DISCOVER THE RESEARCH THAT OCCURS ON THE SAN DIEGO BAY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND OTHER REFUGES NATIONWIDE. THE LIVING COAST WILL CONDUCT LIVING LAB FIELD TRIPS FOR SAN DIEGO COUNTY STUDENTS (GRADES 3- 12). IN COLLABORATION WITH USFWS STAFF, THE LIVING COAST WILL PROVIDE HANDS-ON, STANDARDS-BASED URBAN REFUGE NATURE EXPLORERS PROGRAMS FOR 46 CLASSES (UP TO 1,472 STUDENTS) FROM UNDERSERVED AND TITLE 1 SCHOOLS. ADDITIONALLY, EVERY FIELD TRIP CLASS WILL PARTICIPATE IN A HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT ON THE REFUGE. LIVING COAST WILL ALSO CONDUCT ITS URBAN REFUGE NATURE EXPLORERS SCHOOL OUTREACH PROGRAM IN CLASSROOMS FOR 12 CLASSES (UP TO 384 STUDENTS) FROM UNDERSERVED AND TITLE 1 SCHOOLS IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY.THE SWEETWATER SAFARI PROGRAM PROVIDES AN OPPORTUNITY FOR GUESTS TO EXPLORE THE REFUGE TRAILS, USE SCIENTIFIC TOOLS, AND LEARN ABOUT LOCAL PLANTS AND WILDLIFE WHILE VISITING THE LIVING COAST DISCOVERY CENTER. GROUPS CAN SELECT TO PARTICIPATE IN EDUCATOR-GUIDED OR SELF-GUIDED TOURS OF THE REFUGE TO GAIN AN UP-CLOSE EXPERIENCE WITH THE SWEETWATER MARSH. WITH USFWS SUPPORT, THE LIVING COAST WITH OFFER 40 TOTAL EDUCATOR-GUIDED AND SELF-GUIDED REFUGE-BASED PROGRAMS TO GIVE GUESTS THE OPPORTUNITY TO EXPLORE THE REFUGE, USE SCIENTIFIC TOOLS, AND EXPERIENCE NATURE, REACHING OVER 500 PEOPLE, INCLUDING BOTH ENGLISH- AND SPANISH-SPEAKING GUESTS.

SAN DIEGO IS A BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOT, CONTAINING GREATER DIVERSITY OF LIFE THAN ANY OTHER COUNTY IN THE CONTINENTAL UNITED STATES. IT IS ALSO HOME TO THE GREATEST NUMBER OF PLANT AND ANIMAL SPECIES THREATENED WITH EXTINCTION ANYWHERE IN THE COUNTRY. MEANWHILE, THE INCREASINGLY URBAN AND RACIALLY DIVERSE COMMUNITIES OF EAST COUNTY SAN DIEGO HAVE SOME OF THE POOREST ACCESS TO NATURE AND GREEN SPACES ANYWHERE IN THE COUNTY. THIS PROGRAM AIMS TO OVERCOME THE BARRIERS PEOPLE FROM THESE UNDER-RESOURCED COMMUNITIES FACE TO MEANINGFULLY CONNECT WITH NATURE, AND TO ENGAGE THEM AS PARTNERS IN CONSERVATION.EARTH DISCOVERY INSTITUTE WILL PARTNER WITH THE USFWS TO PROVIDE TWO, 3-HOUR FIELD VISITS (ONE TO A SAN DIEGO REFUGE) TO 250 STUDENTS FROM TITLE 1 SCHOOLS THAT SERVE DIVERSE POPULATIONS (AT LEAST 50% NON-WHITE). STUDENTS WILL PLANT A MINIMUM OF 125 NATIVE PLANTS ON A SAN DIEGO REFUGE PROPERTY TO SUPPORT HABITAT RESTORATION. WE WILL PARTICIPATE IN A TOTAL OF THREE COMMUNITY OUTREACH EVENTS, IN EL CAJON, CHULA VISTA, AND ONE INDIGENOUS COMMUNITY TO ENGAGING A MINIMUM OF 300 PEOPLE. WE WILL AIM TO ENGAGE AT LEAST 50 NEW PEOPLE TO RECEIVE EDI'S NEWSLETTER WITH INFORMATION AND INVITATIONS TO UPCOMING EVENTS, AND SOME PROPORTION OF THESE TO PARTICIPATE IN INTERPRETIVE EVENTS. EDI STAFF WILL LEAD TWO GUIDED NATURE HIKES ON A WILDLIFE REFUGE, WITH THE AIM OF ENGAGING AT LEAST 30 COMMUNITY MEMBERS. AND LASTLY EDI WILL WORK WITH A MINIMUM OF 6 VOLUNTEERS TO PERFORM AT LEAST 400 HOURS OF HABITAT OR INFRASTRUCTURE ENHANCEMENT WORK DURING 28 WEEKLY EVENTS ON A WILDLIFE REFUGE. WORK WILL BE COMPLETED UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE REFUGE MANAGER AND BIOLOGIST.

OVER THE IMPACT PERIOD JULY 1, 2022 - JUNE 30, 2023, OUTDOOR OUTREACH WILL PROVIDE 200+ PROGRAMS IN LOCAL REFUGES AND ADJACENT AREAS FOR 1,000 INDIVIDUAL YOUTH. THROUGH RECREATIONAL LEARNING ACTIVITIES LIKE KAYAKING, MOUNTAIN BIKING, SURFING, HIKING, AND STEWARDSHIP, OUTDOOR OUTREACH WILL CREATE AN ENVIRONMENT IN WHICH PARTICIPANTS FEEL SAFE AND WELCOME, BOTH IN THE OUTDOORS AND SPECIFICALLY IN WILDLIFE REFUGES. BY FORGING AN AUTHENTIC CONNECTION BETWEEN URBAN YOUTH AND CLOSE-TO-HOME OPEN SPACE AREAS, OUTDOOR OUTREACH CAN BUILD STEPPING STONES OF ENGAGEMENT THAT INSPIRE YOUTH PARTICIPANTS TO RESPECT AND PROTECT THE PLACES WHERE THEY PLAY.FURTHERMORE, ROBUST RECREATIONAL LEARNING PROGRAMS PROVIDE AN IMPORTANT PIPELINE OF ENGAGED YOUTH TO APPLY TO AND JOIN OUTDOOR OUTREACH'S LEADERSHIP PROGRAM, WHICH PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUNG ADULTS TO EARN A PAYCHECK, BUILD OUTDOOR LEADERSHIP SKILLS, AND EXPLORE CONSERVATION-BASED CAREER PATHWAYS WHILE STAYING CONNECTED TO SCHOOL. THE LEADERSHIP PROGRAM PROVIDES AN INNOVATIVE AND RESPONSIVE MECHANISM TO FURTHER USFWS'S MISSION TO URBAN AUDIENCES, WHILE ALSO BUILDING OUTDOOR OUTREACH'S CAPACITY THROUGH A PIPELINE OF SKILLED INSTRUCTORS WHO REPRESENT THE DIVERSITY OF THE YOUTH WE SERVE.FINALLY, OUTDOOR OUTREACH AND THE USFWS WILL WORK TOGETHER TO INSTALL THE "FINAL PIPE" TO OUR WORKFORCE DIVERSITY PIPELINE THROUGH A COLLABORATIVE INTERNSHIP PROGRAM. ONE SAN DIEGO YOUTH WILL BE HIRED AS AN INTERN TO GAIN 24 WEEKS OF WORK EXPERIENCE IN NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, OUTDOOR INTERPRETATION AND EDUCATION, AND COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT OVER THE COURSE OF THE GRANT PERIOD. THIS YOUNG LEADER WILL WORK WITH THE VISITOR SERVICES STAFF TO SUPPORT THE EFFORTS OF THE SOCAL URBAN WILDLIFE REFUGE PROGRAM. THE INTERN WILL FOCUS ON DEVELOPING AND DELIVERING EDUCATION AND INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMMING BOTH ON AND OFFSITE IN SAN DIEGO COMMUNITIES. THE INTERN WILL ATTEND COMMUNITY MEETINGS AND OTHER EVENTS AS NEEDED, AND WILL HELP IN REFUGE OUTREACH EFFORTS TO SUPPORT PARTNERS.IMPORTANTLY, OUTDOOR OUTREACH WILL PAY THIS INTERN $15/HOUR FOR UP TO 960 HOURS OF INTERNSHIP WORK, HELPING TO ALLEVIATE THE FINANCIAL BURDEN THAT OFTEN LIMITS LOW-INCOME AND UNDERREPRESENTED YOUTH FROM PARTICIPATING PROFESSIONALLY IN UNPAID CONSERVATION AND OUTDOOR EDUCATION/RECREATIVE INTERNSHIPS.

WE ARE DEDICATED TO PARTNERING WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO SUPPORT SCIENCE TEACHERS AND THEIR STUDENTS FOR THE BENEFIT OF WILDLIFE AND WILD PLACES. THROUGH THE PROPOSED PROGRAM, WE WILL PROVIDE FREE SCIENCE-BASED LABORATORY AND FIELD RESEARCH EXPERIENCES TO 16 SCIENCE TEACHERS AND APPROXIMATELY 512 STUDENTS FROM TITLE I SCHOOLS ACROSS SAN DIEGO AND LOS ANGELES COUNTIES. TITLE I SCHOOLS ARE THOSE WITH 40% OF THEIR STUDENT BODY LIVING AT OR BELOW POVERTY LEVEL, AND ARE ESPECIALLY IMPORTANT TO TARGET AS ATTENDING STUDENTS TYPICALLY HAVE LIMITED OPPORTUNITIES FOR OUT-OF-SCHOOL LEARNING. THE MAJORITY OF STUDENTS AND TEACHERS THAT ENGAGE WITH OUR CONSERVATION SCIENCE PROGRAMS VISIT US FROM TITLE I CAMPUSES WHICH REQUIRE FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE TO PARTICIPATE. THERE ARE CURRENTLY VERY FEW CONSERVATION-ORIENTED FIELD TRIPS OFFERED IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, MOST ESPECIALLY AT THE HIGH SCHOOL LEVEL. THERE ARE ALSO VERY FEW FIELD TRIPS THAT INVOLVE LOCAL SCIENCE STUDENTS DIRECTLY IN RELEVANT AND INNOVATIVE RESEARCH PROJECTS. THE PROGRAM TARGETS DISADVANTAGED TITLE I SCHOOLS WITH THE MOST CRITICAL NEED FOR FREE, HIGH QUALITY CONSERVATION SCIENCE PROGRAMMING FOR THE STUDENTS AND TEACHERS, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON LOW-INCOME URBAN AREAS.PARTICIPATING TEACHERS FIRST ENGAGE WITH OUR TEACHER WORKSHOPS IN CONSERVATION SCIENCE WHICH ARE DESIGNED TO: (1) PROVIDE REPLICABLE, RELEVANT, STANDARDS-BASED CONSERVATION SCIENCE ACTIVITIES FOR FORMAL AND INFORMAL EDUCATION SETTINGS, (2) CONNECT SCIENCE EDUCATORS TO WILDLIFE CONSERVATION THROUGH RELEVANT LABORATORY AND FIELD-BASED EXPERIENCES THAT SHARE RECENT ADVANCES IN CONSERVATION RESEARCH, AND (3) PROVIDE A FORUM FOR SCIENCE EDUCATORS TO NETWORK AND SHARE IDEAS FOR WEAVING CONSERVATION THEMES INTO THEIR SCHOOL COMMUNITY AND ENGAGING STUDENTS IN CONSERVATION. THE WORKSHOP CURRICULUM ADDRESSES A WIDE RANGE OF TOPICS FROM A MULTITUDE OF SCIENTIFIC DISCIPLINES INCLUDING SPATIAL ECOLOGY, RESTORATION AND REINTRODUCTION BIOLOGY, GENETIC RECOVERY, REPRODUCTIVE ENDOCRINOLOGY, GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE, AND THE HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF CONSERVATION. THE CURRICULUM ALSO INCLUDES A GROUP PROJECT THAT ENGAGES TEACHERS IN THE FULL PROCESS OF OPEN INQUIRY AND TEACHES THEM HOW TO GUIDE THIS IMPORTANT PROCESS WITH THEIR STUDENTS. AS PART OF THE PROJECT, PARTICIPANTS MAKE SCIENTIFIC OBSERVATIONS ON THE GROUNDS OF THE SAN DIEGO ZOO SAFARI PARK, DEVELOP COMPARATIVE QUESTIONS, DEVISE INVESTIGATIONS TO ANSWER THEIR QUESTIONS, AND COMMUNICATE THEIR RESULTS TO THE COHORT. THIS TYPE OF FIRSTHAND, EXPERIMENTAL LEARNING ENCOURAGES INDEPENDENT AND CRITICAL THINKING, INCREASING PARTICIPANTS' AWARENESS OF AND CONCERN FOR THE LOCAL ENVIRONMENT AND IT'S INHABITANTS.TO EXTEND THE WORKSHOP EXPERIENCE DIRECTLY TO STUDENTS, WE WILL INVITE OUR NEW WORKSHOP ALUMNI AND THEIR STUDENTS TO ENGAGE WITH OUR OUTDOOR LEARNING LAB (OLL) AND ASSOCIATE "LIFE IN A BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOT" INTERACTIVE FIELD RESEARCH CURRICULUM WHICH IS DESIGNED TO: (1) ENHANCE STUDENTS' INQUIRY AND CRITICAL THINKING SKILLS AS THEY DISCOVER AND MONITOR NATIVE SPECIES, (2) INCREASE THEIR INTEREST IN STEM CAREERS RELATED TO SPECIES RECOVERY, AND (3) ENHANCE APPRECIATION OF THEIR UNIQUE NATURAL HERITAGE AND HOW HUMAN ACTIVITIES IMPACT THE HEALTH AND COMPOSITION OF LOCAL ECOSYSTEMS. THE FIELD-BASED RESEARCH EXPERIENCE IN THE OUTDOOR LEARNING LAB WILL CONNECT STUDENTS TO NATURE AS THEY LEARN ABOUT AND OBSERVE THE NATIVE PLANTS AND ANIMALS THAT ARE PART OF THE CALIFORNIA FLORISTIC PROVINCE, OUR OWN LOCAL BIODIVERSITY HOTSPOT. STUDENTS WILL ENGAGE WITH RESOURCES THAT ENCOURAGE THEM TO CRITICALLY EVALUATE HOW HUMAN-MEDIATED CHANGE IN OUR ENVIRONMENT RELATES TO CHANGES IN FIRE REGIMES, WATER USAGE, AND ULTIMATELY LOSS OF LOCAL BIODIVERSITY IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA AND BEYOND, WITH THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF INSPIRING ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP. THEY WILL VISIT THE SAN DIEGO ZOO SAFARI PARK TO OBSERVE ENDANGERED SPECIES AND CURRENT FIELD PROJECTS IN ACTION.

THE TARGET AUDIENCE OF OUR WILDLIFE RANGERS PROGRAM IS FIFTH-GRADE STUDENTS ENROLLED AT SCHOOLS IN THE SOUTHERN HALF OF SAN DIEGO COUNTY THAT ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE TITLE I FUNDING. RESEARCH SHOWS THERE IS A DIRECT CORRELATION BETWEEN SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS AND ACCESS TO NATURE AND OUTDOOR SPACES--NAMELY THAT THE LOWER THE MEDIAN INCOME IN AN URBAN AREA, THE LESS LIKELY THAT STUDENTS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO NATURE. THROUGH THIS PROPOSED PARTNERSHIP WITH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE, SAN DIEGO ZOO WILDLIFE ALLIANCE WILL RESPOND TO THIS CHALLENGE BY CONNECTING FIFTH-GRADE STUDENTS FROM TITLE I SCHOOLS IN SOUTHERN SAN DIEGO COUNTY TO OUR NATIVE WILDERNESS THROUGH INTERACTIVE CLASSROOM PROGRAMMING AND IMMERSIVE FIELD TRIPS TO THEIR LOCAL WATERSHED HABITAT. IN THE EVENT THAT SCHOOLS ARE NOT CONDUCTING IN-PERSON LEARNING OR ABLE TO OFFER FIELD TRIPS AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, WE WILL CONTINUE TO DELIVER THE PROGRAM VIRTUALLY. OUR PROGRAM ALIGNS WITH THE GOALS OF THE SOCAL URBAN WILDLIFE REFUGE PROJECT BY ENGAGING STUDENTS IN CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES THAT PROMOTE IN THEM A CONCERN AND PASSION TO PROTECT THE NATURAL WORLD. WE WILL CONCENTRATE OUR RECRUITING EFFORTS IN THE DISTRICTS WITH THE HIGHEST PERCENTAGE OF STUDENTS ELIGIBLE FOR FREE AND REDUCED PRICE MEALS, WHICH IS CORRELATED WITH HIGHER RATES OF POVERTY.

ESTABLISH A PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PILOT PROGRAM WITH CENTRAL HIGH SCHOOL, AN LAUSD CONTINUATION HIGH SCHOOL WITH 25 DIFFERENT SITES THROUGHOUT LOS ANGELES, SERVING SOME OF LAUSD'S HIGHEST-NEEDS STUDENTS. THE PROGRAM WILL BE INTRODUCED TO ALL CENTRAL HS EDUCATORS VIA AN ONLINE ZOOM WORKSHOP, THEN EACH SUB-CAMPUS LOCATION WILL BE VISITED TO PROVIDE SITE-SPECIFIC 1-HOUR TEACHER WORKSHOPS, GUIDING TEACHERS ON HOW TO UTILIZE RESOURCES FOUND ON THEIR OUTDOOR CAMPUS TO INCORPORATE NATURE-BASED ACTIVITIES INTO EXISTING CURRICULAR GOALS, HOW TO USE BINOCULARS, COMPASS, AND OTHER WAYS TO ENGAGE STUDENTS WITH EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING TECHNIQUES.PROVIDE A 3-HOUR EXPLORATION OF THE BALLONA WETLANDS TO A MINIMUM OF 500 3-5TH GRAND STUDENTS FROM TITLE 1 SCHOOLS THAT SERVE DIVERSE POPULATIONS (MORE THAN 50% NON-WHITE).PROVIDE A 3-HOUR VISIT TO KENNETH HAHN STATE RECREATION AREA (KHSRA) TO A MINIMUM OF 300 3-6TH GRAND STUDENTS FROM TITLE 1 SCHOOLS THAT SERVE DIVERSE POPULATIONS (MORE THAN 50% NON-WHITE).PROVIDE A 3-HOUR VISIT TO DOCKWEILER BEACH TO A MINIMUM OF 300 3-6TH GRADE STUDENTS FROM TITLE 1 SCHOOLS THAT SERVE DIVERSE POPULATIONS (MORE THAN 50% NON-WHITE).HOST A 3-HOUR HABITAT RESTORATION EVENT FOR APPROXIMATELY 50 COMMUNITY MEMBERS, LED BY STAFF AS WELL AS HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE STUDENTS IN OUR PROGRAMS.

FOR THIS STRATEGY TO SIGNIFICANTLY INCREASE THE PACE, SCALE, AND QUALITY OF ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION  SEEDS OF SUCCESS IS THE NATIONAL NATIVE SEED COLLECTION PROGRAM, LED BY THE BUREAU OF LAND MANAGEMENT
