MATERIALS AVAILABLE FOR RESTORING AND SUPPORTING RESILIENT ECOSYSTEMS  THE NORTHEAST REGION OF THE U S  FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE HAS A GROWING NEED FOR NATIVE SEED TO SUPPORT HABITAT RESTORATIONS FOR CLIMATE RESILIENCE AS WELL AS THREATENED AND ENDANGERED SPECIES AT RISK SPECIES, MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE PLANTS, AND HABITAT ENHANCEMENTS ON PRIVATE LANDS  WILDLAND NATIVE SEED COLLECTIONS ARE THE FOUNDATION FOR NATIVE PLANT MATERIALS DEVELOPMENT AND ARE ESSENTIAL FOR RESTORING WORKING LANDSCAPES AND WILDLIFE HABITAT AFTER NATURAL DISASTERS AND OTHER DAMAGE  THE PURPOSE OF THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS FOR THE NORTHEAST REGION OF THE U S, FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE TO WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NATIVE PLANT TRUST TO DEVELOP A NATIVE SEED NETWORK WITHIN NEW ENGLAND AND INCREASE THE AVAILABILITY OF HIGH PRIORITY NATIVE SEED FOR CONSERVATION NATIVE PLANT TRUST IS THE ONLY ORGANIZATION IN NEW ENGLAND CURRENTLY POSITIONED TO SERVE AS A  REGIONAL SEED HUB  WHICH IS SEEKING TO COORDINATE A REGIONAL NATIVE SEED NETWORK  FRAMEWORK FOR THE INTERORGANIZATIONAL MANAGEMENT OF THE REGION S SEED RESOURCES AND SEED BANK   NATIVE PLANT TRUST HAS A MISSION CALLING FOR SEED GROWN NATIVE PLANTS, A DESIRE TO EXPAND SEED AVAILABILITY, ROOM FOR EXPANSION OF NATIVE PLANT TRUST S SEED FACILITIES, AND EXPERTISE IN ALL ASPECTS OF PROCESSING AND BANKING SEED AND PROPAGATING EVEN HARD TO GROW NEW ENGLAND NATIVE PLANTS  FOR DECADES NATIVE PLANT TRUST HAS MANAGED THE SOLE SEED BANK OF RARE AND ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES IN NEW ENGLAND, AND HAVE APPLIED THIS KNOWLEDGE TO MORE COMMON NATIVE PLANT SPECIES AS THE NASAMI FARM NURSERY HAS GROWN  STAFF ARE TRAINED IN ALL ASPECTS OF SEED CLEANING, DRYING, FREEZING, AND LONG TERM STORAGE  THE PROTOCOLS FOR PRESERVING SEEDS CAN VARY BY SPECIES, AND WITH DECADES OF EXPERIENCE WITH BOTH RARE AND COMMON SPECIES, NATIVE PLANT TRUST IS BEST TO SERVE AS THE REGIONAL SEED HUB  BY HELPING TO BUILD A NATIVE SEED PIPELINE, NATIVE PLANT TRUST CAN INCREASE THE NATIVE SEEDS AND PLANTS AVAILABLE FOR ECOLOGICAL RESTORATION THAT ARE OF LOCAL PROVENANCE AND ARE NOT CLONES OF PLANTS FROM ELSEWHERE IN THE COUNTRY THAT MAY NOT THRIVE IN THE LOCAL THIS PROJECT WILL INVOLVE A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE FRIENDS OF OTTAWA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE AND THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE. THE FRIENDS AND THE SERVICE HAVE A LOT OF COMMON GOALS AND OBJECTIVES WITHIN THEIR RESPECTIVE PROGRAMS. THE FRIENDS WORK TO PROVIDE INTERN STIPENDS TO SEVERAL INTERNS EACH YEAR. THIS PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A CAREER LADDER WITH THE SERVICE, ALLOWING INDIVIDUALS TO NETWORK AND EXPAND THEIR ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES WHILE ACCOMPLISHING RESTORATION AND EDUCATION EFFORTS AT OTTAWA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. WORKING TOGETHER, THE FRIENDS AND THE SERVICE WILL IDENTIFY INDIVIDUALS TO HIRE INTO INTERN OR ENTRY LEVEL POSITIONS TO FOCUS ON PROJECTS CRITICAL TO THE REFUGE'S MISSION. THE FRIENDS WILL ASSIST WITH ADMINISTRATIVE PORTIONS OF THE PROGRAM AND PROVIDE LIVING STIPENDS FOR INTERNS AND WAGES FOR INDEPENDENT CONTRACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH THE PROGRAM.

PRAIRIE PLANTINGS CONSISTING OF A MIXTURE OF NATIVE GRASSES AND FORBS ARE ONE OF THE MOST THREATENED NATURAL COMMUNITIES IN THE MIDWEST. INVASIVE PLANTS LIKE WILD CARROT AND WILD PARSNIP COMMONLY INVADE AND DOMINATE ESTABLISHED PRAIRIES IN THE ST. CROIX WMD, REDUCING THE BENEFITS OF NATIVE PRAIRIES. METHODS THAT SUCCESSFULLY CONTROL THESE SPECIES EXIST BUT ARE DIFFICULT TO USE IN PRAIRIE SYSTEMS WITHOUT SEVERELY IMPACTING NATIVE FORB SPECIES. HERBICIDES ARE A CONTROL OPTION, BUT THEY INJURE/REMOVE NATIVE FORB SPECIES, THEREFORE THEY ARE RARELY USED. A NEW HERBICIDE, FLORPYRAUXIFEN, SHOWS PROMISE AS AN ALTERNATIVE OPTION FOR CONTROL. IT IS HIGHLY EFFECTIVE AT CONTROLLING WILD PARSNIP AND WILD CARROT AND MANY FORBS HAVE TOLERANCE TO THIS PRODUCT. WE PROPOSE TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THIS NEW HERBICIDE IN 1) CONTROLLING WILD PARSNIP AND WILD CARROT AND 2) INJURY TO DESIRABLE VEGETATION AS A RESULT OF APPLICATION. AS AREAS ARE OFTEN BURNED OR MOWED PRIOR TO APPLICATION AN ADDITIONAL GOAL IS TO DETERMINE IF INTEGRATING THESE METHODS IMPROVES RESULTS. IF THIS PROJECT IS SUCCESSFUL, EFFECTIVE WILD PARSNIP/WILD CARROT BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES WOULD BE DEVELOPED THAT WOULD PROVIDE LONG-LASTING CONTROL WHILE LIMITING INJURY TO DESIRABLE FORB SPECIES. THIS WOULD ALLOW FOR EFFECTIVE MANAGEMENT OF THESE INVASIVE SPECIES AND PREVENT ANY IMPACTS TO THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES THESE PRAIRIES PROVIDE.

THE METRO YOUTH CLIMATE CONVERGENCE BRINGS TOGETHER PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO UNITE HIGH SCHOOL YOUTH ACROSS RACE, CULTURE AND NEIGHBORHOOD TO IDENTIFY LOCAL CLIMATE JUSTICE ISSUES AND CLIMATE SOLUTIONS THEY CAN TAKE IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. THROUGH THIS PROJECT CLIMATE GENERATION WILL WORK WITH METRO AREA YOUTH SERVING COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO EMPOWER YOUTH TO BUILD RELATIONSHIPS, TAKE LEADERSHIP IN THEIR COMMUNITIES AND CHANGE THE NARRATIVE OF WHAT CLIMATE ACTION LOOKS LIKE IN THE TWIN CITIES. A COALITION OF YOUTH LEADERS WILL JOIN TOGETHER FROM MULTIPLE YOUTH ORGANIZATIONS IN COMMUNITIES SURROUNDING THE MINNESOTA VALLEY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE FOR A SUMMER INTENSIVE WHERE THEY WILL VISIT ONE ANOTHER AND LEARN FROM LOCAL CLIMATE CHAMPIONS, SHARE CLIMATE ACTIONS WITH THEIR COMMUNITIES, GAIN SKILLS TO LEAD IN THEIR OWN COMMUNITIES, AND PLAN A CULMINATING YOUTH CONVERGENCE EVENT AT THE MINNESOTA VALLEY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE TO ELEVATE LOCAL STORIES AND SOLUTIONS.

DUCKS UNLIMITED, INC. (DU) PLANS TO PROVIDE ENGINEERING SERVICES, INCLUDING SURVEY, DESIGN, AND CONSTRUCTION MANAGEMENT WITH USFWS SHIAWASSEE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE TO RESTORE THE GREENPOINT LONG POND. GREENPOINT OPERATED AS A GOLF COURSE UNTIL 1988, AND WAS DONATED TO USFWS IN 2014. THE LONG POND WAS BUILT AS AN IRRIGATION POND FOR THE GOLF COURSE, AND THE EXISTING WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE IS NON-OPERATIONAL. IN ADDITION, THE POND IS STEEP, WITH NEARLY 1:1 SIDE SLOPES, WITH LITTLE TO NO QUALITY VEGETATION. DU AND USFWS CAN RESTORE THE POND TO A QUALITY FLOODPLAIN WETLAND BY REPLACING THE WATER CONTROL STRUCTURE AND SOFTENING THE SIDE SLOPES. THE BIOLOGICAL GOAL OF THE WETLAND RESTORATION IS TO SIMULATE A BACKWATER MARSH WITH A DIRECT CONNECTION TO THE TITTABAWASSEE RIVER. THE COMPLETE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO TAKE TWO-THREE YEARS. THE ESTIMATED COST TO COMPLETE ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES IS $756,200, INCLUDING $736,519 IN DIRECT PROJECT EXPENSES.
A COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT SPECIALIST WILL WORK WITH STAFF AT LENAPE NWR COMPLEX TO REACH NEW AUDIENCES AND CREATE SUSTAINABLE CONNECTION WITH URBAN PARTNERSHIPS IN YONKERS, NY AND ELIZABETH, NJ.

DUCKS UNLIMITED, INC (DU) AND U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (FWS) OTTAWA NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE (ONWR) WILL COLLABORATE TO PROTECT AND RESTORE LAND TO EXPAND ONWR. DU AND FWS WILL IDENTIFY AND PRIORITIZE PROPERTIES FOR PROTECTION AND RESTORATION WITHIN THE ACQUISITION BOUNDARY OF THE REFUGE. DU WILL PURCHASE PROPERTIES AND DONATE EACH PROPERTY TO FWS. AFTER DONATION, DU AND FWS WILL COLLABORATE TO RESTORE AND ENHANCE WETLANDS AND OTHER HABITAT TYPES ON EACH PROPERTY. RESTORED WETLANDS WILL BE CONNECTED TO ADJACENT RIVERS OR STREAMS WITH WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES TO PROVIDE ACCESS FOR FISH INTO THE WETLANDS FOR SPAWNING. RESTORED AND ENHANCED WETLANDS ALSO MAY INCLUDE THE CONSTRUCTION OF LEVEES AND THE INSTALLATION OF WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES AND PUMPS TO PROVIDE WATER LEVEL MANAGEMENT INFRASTRUCTURE THAT WILL HELP FWS MANAGE AND SUSTAIN QUALITY HABITAT.AT LEAST TWO PROPERTIES TOTALING +/- 110 ACRES WILL BE ACQUIRED UNDER THIS PROJECT WITH TWO PROPERTIES INITIALLY IDENTIFIED FOR ACQUISITION. AT LEAST 25 ACRES OF WETLANDS WITH FISH PASSAGE WILL BE RESTORED. THE PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF THESE PROPERTIES WILL ADDRESS THE LOSS OF FISH HABITAT IN THE MAUMEE AREA OF CONCERN. FWS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR THE LONG-TERM OPERATIONS AND MAINTENANCE OF EACH PROPERTY PROTECTED AND RESTORED.

FUNDS UNDER THIS AWARD WILL ALLOW FRIENDS OF NEVADA WILDERNESS TO CONTINUE A MULTI-YEAR HABITAT RESTORATION AND REHABILITATION PROJECT ON LANDS WITHIN THE SHELDON NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, INCLUDING PROPOSED WILDERNESS AREAS. USING A FOUR PERSON CREW, FNW WILL CONTINUE PRIORITY WORK AS DETERMINED BY THE REFUGE STAFF SUCH AS: LOCATION AND REMOVAL OF INTERIOR FENCING AND NON-FUNCTIONING WATER DEVELOPMENTS; SPRING REHABILITATION; INVENTORY AND TREATMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES; POSTING OF PROPOSED WILDERNESS BOUNDARY SIGNS; REMOVAL OF CLOSED ROAD/ROUTE SEGMENTS IN PROPOSED WILDERNESS; PROTECTING RIPARIAN HABITATS BY CONSTRUCTING EXCLOSURE FENCES; AND MONITORING AND REPAIRING EXTERIOR BOUNDARY FENCING TO PREVENT FERAL HORSES FROM ENTERING THE REFUGE.

THE RUFA SUBSPECIES OF THE RED KNOT HAS DECLINED PRECIPITOUSLY OVER THE PAST FOUR DECADES LEADING THE UNITED STATES FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (USFWS) TO FORMALLY LIST THE POPULATION AS FEDERALLY THREATENED UNDER THE ENDANGERED SPECIES ACT. ONE COMPONENT OF THEIR COMPLEX ANNUAL CYCLE IS A FINAL REFUELING EVENT IN MAY BEFORE LEAVING ON THEIR ULTIMATE FLIGHT TO BREEDING GROUNDS IN THE HIGH ARCTIC. CONDITIONS WITHIN SPRING STAGING SITES ALONG THE WESTERN ATLANTIC COAST ARE CONSIDERED CRITICAL TO THE FUTURE OF THE RUFA POPULATION BECAUSE RESOURCES ACQUIRED WITHIN THESE SITES ALLOW BIRDS TO COMPLETE THEIR FLIGHT TO THE ARCTIC AND ARRIVE WITH ENOUGH SURPLUS TO INITIATE REPRODUCTION AND TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE SHORT BREEDING SEASON. ALTHOUGH A GREAT DEAL OF WORK WITH RED KNOTS DURING SPRING HAS BEEN CONDUCTED WITHIN DELAWARE BAY, WE KNOW MUCH LESS ABOUT THE IMPORTANCE OF STAGING AREAS SOUTH OF THIS AREA. OVER THE PAST TWO YEARS, NUMBERS OF KNOTS USING DELAWARE BAY HAVE DROPPED UNEXPECTEDLY RAISING THE POSSIBILITY THAT 1) THE POPULATION HAS EXPERIENCED A RAPID DECLINE OR 2) BIRDS ARE SHIFTING TO OTHER STAGING SITES. THIS EVENT HAS HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR A MORE COMPREHENSIVE MONITORING PROGRAM THAT INCLUDES THE PORTION OF THE ATLANTIC COAST THAT SUPPORTS STAGING KNOTS.WE WILL CONDUCT TWO AERIAL SURVEYS (SCHEDULED WINDOWS 9-12 AND 18-22 MAY) TO ASSESS THE STATUS AND DISTRIBUTION OF STAGING RED KNOTS ALONG THE WESTERN ATLANTIC COAST. SURVEYS WILL INCLUDE THE OUTER COASTAL BEACHES (800 KM) FROM CAPE HENLOPEN, DE THROUGH LITTLE RIVER INLET, NC. THIS SURVEY WILL BE COORDINATED WITH SURVEYS COVERING OTHER AREAS OF THE ATLANTIC COAST FROM NEW JERSEY THROUGH NORTH FLORIDA. SURVEYS WILL BE CONDUCTED USING A HIGH-WING CESSNA 172 AIRCRAFT FLYING 10-25 M ABOVE THE GROUND. BIRDS WILL BE FLUSHED FROM THE SURFACE TO FACILITATE IDENTIFICATION AND NUMERICAL ESTIMATION. RED KNOT FLOCKS WILL BE MAPPED USING A GPS-ENABLED TABLET AND INFORMATION ON FLOCK SIZE AND HABITAT USE WILL BE RECORDED.INFORMATION COLLECTED DURING THE TWO SURVEY PERIODS WILL BE MERGED WITH OTHER COORDINATED EFFORTS ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST TO DEVELOP A MORE COMPREHENSIVE UNDERSTANDING OF CURRENT RED KNOT POPULATION SIZE AND STAGING DISTRIBUTION. A GEO-REFERENCED SURVEY FILE WILL BE PRODUCED AND DELIVERED TO USFWS. THIS FILE MAY BE USED TO ASSESS CURRENT POPULATION SIZE BUT ALSO TO DETERMINE THE USE OF SPECIFIC CONSERVATION UNITS (E.G., FEDERAL, STATE, NGO AND CORPORATE PROPERTIES) ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST. THIS GRANULAR INFORMATION WILL GREATLY IMPROVE OUR UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPORTANCE OF SPECIFIC PROPERTIES FOR STAGING RED KNOTS FOR FUTURE PLANNING EFFORTS.

FUNDING OPPORTUNITY NUMBER:F-FWS-NWRS-22-037CFDAS:15.654APPLICANT NAME:THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN MISSISSIPPIDESCRIPTIVE TITLE OF APPLICANT'S PROJECT:SPATIAL ECOLOGY OF ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLES AND ASSOCIATED HERPETOFAUNAL SURVEYPROJECT ABSTRACT:THE PROJECT WILL USE RADIO-TELEMETRY TO TRACK THE MOVEMENTS, SPATIAL USAGE, AND HABITAT USAGE OF ALLIGATOR SNAPPING TURTLES IN BOTH PANTHER SWAMP AND HILLSIDE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES. THIS WILL INCLUDE OBSERVATIONS OF WHERE THE TURTLES CHOOSE TO BE, HOW OFTEN AND HOW FAR THEY MOVE, AND HOW THESE MAY CHANGE SEASONALLY (I.E., NESTING SEASON, FLOOD AND NON-FLOOD CONDITIONS). WE WILL ALSO RECORD HABITAT CONDITIONS ALONG WITH TURTLE LOCATIONS TO ASSESS PARTICULAR HABITAT ATTRIBUTES THAT MAY BE OF PARTICULAR IMPORTANCE FOR THIS SPECIES. IN ADDITION TO THIS STUDY, WE WILL ALSO USE A VARIETY OF SURVEY TECHNIQUES TO ESTABLISH A BASELINE INVENTORY OF AMPHIBIAN AND REPTILE SPECIES THAT OCCUR ON THESE REFUGES, ESPECIALLY PANTHER SWAMP.

RIO GRANDE RETURN WILL ASSIST IN THE CONSTRUCTION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF RIPARIAN AND WETLAND HABITAT WITHIN THE VALLE DE ORO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE ("VDO").THIS PROPOSAL FOCUSES ON COMPLEMENTING EXISTING RIO GRANDE RETURN INVESTMENTS AT VDO FROM THE NORTH AMERICAN WETLANDS CONSERVATION ACT AND THE NEW MEXICO ENVIRONMENT DEPARTMENT RIVER STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM.

THE PROJECT AREA FOR THIS AGREEMENT IS LOCATED WITHIN SEVEN PRAIRIE POTHOLE JOINT VENTURE PRIORITY COMPLEXES IN IOWA. WITHIN THIS AREA BOTH THE U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE (SERVICE) AND THE IOWA DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (DEPARTMENT) OWN AND MANAGE PROPERTY WITH THE GOAL OF PRODUCING EXCELLENT WATERFOWL AND MIGRATORY BIRD PRODUCTION HABITAT. THE DEPARTMENT, ACTING ON BEHALF OF THE SERVICE, WILL PERFORM THE RESPONSIBILITIES OF REPAIRING AND ENHANCING WETLAND BASINS. ONE WETLAND ON THE RIERSON WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREA HAS A LARGE 32-ACRE MARSH THAT IS RESTORABLE. RESTORATION OF THIS MARSH WILL INVOLVE THE REPLACEMENT OF A 48-INCH CONCRETE CULVERT AND THE INSTALLATION OF AN EMERGENCY SPILLWAY. A SECOND RECENTLY CONSTRUCTED WETLAND ON THE DROMMER WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREA NEEDS SEDIMENT REMOVED TO CREATE A SHALLOW WATER AREA TO PROVIDE SEMI-PERMANENT WATER. THE SERVICE AND DEPARTMENT WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR OVER SITE, PLAN DEVELOPMENT, REVIEW, AND INSPECTION OF THE RESTORATION PROJECTS, ALONG WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF LONG RANGE MANAGEMENT PLANS FOR THE RESTORED WETLAND COMPLEXES. THE WATERFOWL PRODUCTION AREAS BEING REPAIRED AND/OR ENHANCED ARE PART OF THE IOWA WETLAND MANAGEMENT DISTRICTS COMPREHENSIVE CONSERVATION PLAN AND ARE MANAGED ACCORDING TO THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THIS SERVICE APPROVED PLAN. THE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES DESCRIBED HEREIN WILL IMPROVE MIGRATORY BIRD HABITAT AND PUBLIC RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES.

MCKAY DAM, PHASE 1, PHASE 2, PUMPING STATIONS, MONITORING STATIONS, AND THE OXBOW:BOR MAINTAINS THE IRRIGATION CANALS IN AND AROUND THE HERMISTON AREA AS WELL AS MCKAY DAM. SOME OF THE SITES ARE PUMPING STATIONS, MONITORING SITES, CANALS AND A EARTH DAM. THESE AREAS NEED TO BE FREE OF VEGETATION AND MAINTAINED FOR NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL, FIRE, AND PERSONNEL SAFETY. WE DO THIS BY USING BARE GROUND HERBICIDES TO MAINTAIN ZERO VEGETATION FOR THE GROWING SEASON. THE NATURAL AREAS ON THE DAM AND THE OXBOW PROPERTY ARE TREATED TO MAINTAIN AND CONTROL NOXIOUS WEEDS. NOXIOUS WEEDS ARE AN ECONOMIC BURDEN TO THE LANDOWNERS ACROSS THE STATE. BOR IS DOING THEIR PART BY CONTROLLING THE NOXIOUS WEEDS.COLD SPRINGS AND MCKAY REFUGE:COLD SPRINGS AND MCKAY REFUGES HAVE MULTIPLE NOXIOUS WEED SITES THAT HAVE INVADED THE NATURAL AREAS OVER THE YEARS. THESE AREAS WILL BE MAPPED AND CONTROLLED CHEMICALLY. THIS IS THE MOST COST EFFECTIVE METHOD IN THE LONG TERM. BIO CONTROLS WILL BE USED WHEN OPTIONS COME AVAILABLE.THESE AREAS WILL BE TREATED USING THREE METHODS. THE FIRST IS WITH A 4X4 P/U WITH A SPRAYER. THE SECOND IS UTV WITH BOOM AND HAND REEL, AND THE LAST IS WITH A BACK PACK SPRAYER. BOTH BARE GROUND AND NOXIOUS WEED CONTROL APPLICATIONS WILL BE APPLIED USING ONE OF THESE METHODS. IN SOME CASES MANUAL CONTROL WILL BE THE MOST EFFECTIVE METHOD OF CONTROL.BY REMOVING THE UNWANTED VEGETATION CHEMICALLY YOU ARE REDUCING THE ANNUAL MAINTENANCE COST OVER THE COURSE OF THE YEAR FOR THE BARE GROUND AREAS. BY REMOVING THE NOXIOUS WEEDS YOU ARE CREATING NATURAL HABITAT BY REDUCING THE COMPETITION FROM THE NOXIOUS WEEDS. OVERALL IT REDUCES THE ECONOMIC BURDEN IT POSES FOR THE PUBLIC AREAS, AGRICULTURAL LAND, AND NATURAL AREAS.

THE EEJSP AFFIRMS A CROSS-SECTOR COMMITMENT TO ESTABLISH AN ENVIRONMENTALLY AND ECONOMICALLY JUST APPROACH TO GUIDE LAND AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. THE PUBLIC LANDS ALLIANCE (PLA) WAS SELECTED IN OCTOBER 2020 AS THE NATIONAL COOPERATIVE MARKEITNG PARTNER OF THE NATIONAL WILDLIFIE REFUGE SYSTEM (NWRS) TO INCRESAE PRIVATE SUPPORT FOR THE NWRS, EXPAND THE PUBLIC'S UNDERSTAND OF NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE RECREATION OPPORTUNITIES, AND ENHANCE THE NWRS BRAND. IN THE FIRST YEAR OF OUR PARTNERSHIP, PLA HAS DETERMINED THE IRRESISTABLE INVITATION THAT WILL ENTICE CORPORATE PARTNERS, FOUNDATIONS, AND INDIVIDUALS TO JOIN OUR EFFORT MUST INCLUDE:- A ROBUST PUBLIC AWARENESS AND ACTIVATION CAMPAIGN THAT LEVERAGES SOCIAL MEDIA AND DIGITAL ASSETS;- BRANDED PROGRAMS THAT HAVE AN IMPACT ON NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES AND THE AMERICAN PUBLIC; AND- STRONG PARNTERSHIPS WITH FWS FRIENDS GROUPS AND OTHER NWRS PARTNERS TO HELP DEPLOY CAMPAIGN MESSAGES, SELL CAMPAIGN MERCHANDISE, AND IMPLEMENT BRANDED PROGRAMS.PLA IS EXCITED TO CONTINUE TO DEVELOP AND EXECUTE THIS STRATEGY IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NWRS AND ITS PARTNERS THROUGH 2026.
